content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												Half-Life 2, the game that like it's predecessor is seen as a classic. It's time for me to find out if the game still holds up. The story takes place some years after the events of the original Half-Life. Gordon Freeman is woken up by G-Man to find out that the world had been taken by the alien Combine. Gordon is then joined by resistance fighters to find a way to free humanity. The gameplay itself is a mixture of shooting, puzzle solving and exploration much like the first Half-Life game. However, all of this is differently executed in Half-Life 2. In Half-Life 2 everything is even more dynamic, because of objects being destructible and having physics, which can result in some memorable chain reactions. The world felt to me like a real open world game, while it is still a pretty linear game. This has to do with the fact that you are mostly outside and you can explore the different areas and interact with npcs. The world you play in is around the same city area, which means that this time you aren't going to other alien dimensions. When you think about it there aren't actually that many new things in Half-Life 2. But the things that are new still deliver new gameplay. For instance, the gravity gun that you get can grab and shoot objects which is great for murdering and puzzle solving. The gravity gun really adds a playfulness to the game. The other real new weapon is the bug bait which is a ball that you can throw on enemies or destinations, which will result in a group of your own aliens going to it and attacking the enemies. The only problem I had with this is that you can only use this weapon in a certain section.  The other new gameplay feature is that you can now drive a buggy at certain parts. I read people saying that it was the worst part of Half-Life 2. In my opinion even though the buggy feels clunky I loved that part the most. It really gives that open world explorer feeling, because of you have to get out of the vehicle to look around. The sounddesign in this game was also done by the same team as the one that worked on the original Half-Life. I can say that I liked this soundtrack even more than the previous one, because of it having more of its’ own style. The epic music sometimes felt a little off though, but they are still fun to listen to. The sound effects add a quirky feeling, and the voice acting is also professionaly executed. The storytelling of the game was mostly well executed, with also including storytelling through gameplay. Sadly, unlike in its’ predecessor, you are forced at certain parts to listen to conversations. This can be pretty annoying if you have to listen to it again, without the option to skip it. I have to say that overall the world, story and gameplay doesn't feel as flawlesly connected as it was in the previous Half-Life. That probably has to do with the fact that the game also wanted to show everything impressive that the engine could do. The game took me 12 hours to complete so it was shorter than the original Half-Life, but I guess that also has to do with the fact that at the beginning I unknowingly played on the easiest difficulty. Later I found out I could actually change it in the options menu. Even with the complaints I have with Half-Life 2 compared to Half-Life 1, I can still recommend it. The game like its’ predecessor was greatly ahead of its’ time, and at some parts maybe still is. While playing I realized that every futuristic game that I played that came out after Half-Life 2 all had big 'inspiration' from the game.  Half-Life 2 is still adventurous enough that it still holds up. Reviews of the other Half-Life games:Half-LifeHalf-Life: Opposing ForceHalf-Life: Blue Shift

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
Half-Life 2 is an amazing game.Half-Life 2's level design is really good and does a good job at letting you be in a confined space but not letting you feel trapped. It feels authentic in a sense that, if you're in a specific level, you're trapped by actual walls or solid and visible objects; as opposed to invisible objects. Some would think that it might have invisible walls with a futuristic touch, like blue lines going through it, since it is a Sci-Fi game.Half-Life 2 also does an excellent job and making you feel scared. There is one level, Ravenholm, it is absolutely filled with zombies, it is a very dark and eerie level. I remember, the entire time I was playing through it, I was extremely terrified, but had to power through. It was hard.Half-Life 2's combat is pretty spot on, almost no errors anywhere with hitboxes being fine and no noticeable or game-breaking bugs. The game also has a variety of weapons.Half-Life 2 lets you drive 2 vehicles in the game, one of which is a Jeep, it is a very fast land-vehicle. It is mildly difficult to control while at high speeds, which isn't a bad thing, it's to be expected. The Airboat is a fast land and water vehicle which is noticeably difficult to control, at almost any time. The game has a good sue of vehicles in specific levels.Half-Life 2's soundtrack and sounds do sound very modern. The soundtrack is extremely good, and chooses what to play at specific times, but even so, the music it does actually play is very good. Even now, while writing this review, I am listening to part of the soundtrack, Triage at Dawn, it is called. A very, very nice part of the soundtrack. The sounds, even crowbarring a toilet or a wall, do sound very real.The game, I should talk about, doesn't, for me, at least, do an excellent job at keeping you hooked, it took me a while in between play-sessions to get back into it. But I very recently finished it.This all makes out to be a very pleasant gaming experience, and it is highly recommended as a game.91/100

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												Let's get this out of the way: the Source engine is showing its age – later Valve games have incorporated upgrades that are lacking in Half-Life 2. There isn’t much detail compared to more recent games, textures are blurry, and there are problems with lighting and shadows. All of that is true, but it really isn’t fair to criticize the game for that…it was made in 2004, and it looks like it was, but that doesn’t take away from how fun it is to play. And besides, if you’re really concerned about the graphics, you can always download one of the free community mods (Half-Life 2: Update for example) which make it look prettier.On to my thoughts on the gameplay. I think the reason Half-Life 2 was (and still is) so successful is because the gameplay constantly evolves as you progress forward. As soon as you become comfortable, you’re presented with something which changes how you can approach each situation. After playing the beginning – which feels like a fairly standard shooter – you’re given the airboat and giant arenas to play around with. After a while of that, they give you a machine gun on the airboat, changing up how you use it. Then you’re given the gravity gun, and immediately thrust into Ravenholm, a haunting and creepy environment filled with saw blades, barrels, and other things you can throw at enemies. Then comes the dune buggy and ant-lions, and some of my favorite sections of the game. Traveling down Highway 17, dodging ant-lions as you ferret out combine strongholds on the coast, showcases some of the best that Half-Life 2 has to offer.But the game isn’t done throwing new things at you. After fighting the ant-lions, you’re given a tool which makes them your allies, and you use them to assault Nova Prospekt, a claustrophobic prison where you’re given access to automated turrets and have to stand your ground against waves of Combine soldiers. Once you’ve escaped Nova Prospekt, you’re thrown into a full-blown rebellion and given command of a squad of resistance fighters. And then finally, at the end of the game, all of your weapons are taken away except for a super-powered gravity gun, and you get to experience what it’s like to throw men around like rag dolls as you rampage through the citadel.Not all of these are executed perfectly – the squad command sections in particular hilariously showcase the shortcomings of the AI, with companions constantly getting in your way, running out to die from snipers or grenades, and generally acting like morons. Some of the pacing, particularly at the beginning of the game as you run through sewer after sewer and later as you crawl through Nova Prospekt, is tedious and repetitive. But it’s worth playing through those sections to see what comes next, because there’s always something new around the corner.Half-Life 2 still does a far better job than most recent games in shifting the game’s paradigm constantly, and that evolving gameplay makes it successful – and fun to play over a decade later. If it’s been a while since you played it, it’s worth it to revisit it. If you’ve never played it before, it won’t wow you with its looks, but you’ll experience a classic with some of the best gameplay around – and widely considered one of the best games ever made.View the full review here[www.thesewall.com].

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												This is one of the few games where you can believe the hype and not be let down in the slightest.  I had been told for YEARS how much of an experience this was but never gave it a shot... Until now.  My mind was blown from the first few minutes and onward it just got better & better.  A true classic in every way.  From the intensely immersive gameplay to the atmospheric and captivating world - Half Life 2 brings you into City 17 and renders it in a way that feels tangible.  Often times I found myself speaking for Gordon only to realize I was just muttering in sheer awe of the technical marvels presented for the time.  I can see roots of modern games like Last of Us and Bioshock Infinite and how they stemmed from this masterpiece.  10/10, 5 stars, two thumbs up and all of the praise I can give.  Valve needs to put out Half-Life 3 or work on another game similar to this as I know that I would pre-order it instantly.  What a genre bending adventure, worth every penny and every minute!

												Half-Life 2 is one of those games that everyone has, but not everyone has played. I still get surprised whenever I come across someone who spends a lot of time playing games, but hasn't finished (or even played) Half-Life 2.The story telling in this game is fantastic. Technology changes people, gosh.If you have Half-Life 2 in your steam library but haven't yet played or are yet to acquire a copy, I strongly recommend giving it a shot. You won't regret it. 												Half-Life 2 is a first-person shooter game from Valve. It is a sequel to the previous game, Half-Life.The game focus on storyline set after the event of Half-Life, in a City 17 somewhere in Eastern Europe. You play as Gordon Freeman, the protagonist from Half-Life and embark on a new journey as he return from G-man stasis. The world that he once knew has changed, the Combine has taken over. Now he must struggle along with his fellow human resistance for survival.Using the new Source Engine, Half-Life 2 has remarkable graphics and far better than the previous Half-Life game. The new physics are incredible, almost everything is moveable. Textures and effects are also even more beautiful. The best graphics of the time.It's a good classic first-person shooter game with the best story, I recommend this.Rating 10/10

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												Half-Life 2 (stylized as HλLF-LIFE2) is a first-person shooter video game and the sequel to Half-Life (1998). Developed by Valve Corporation, it was released on November 16, 2004, following a five-year $40 million development, during which a substantial part of the project was leaked and distributed on the Internet. The game was developed alongside Valve's Steam software. It introduced the Source game engine and, because of Steam, was the first single-player video game to require online product activation.Some years after the events of Half-Life, protagonist Gordon Freeman is woken by the enigmatic G-Man to find the world has been taken over by the alien Combine. Joined by allies including resistance fighter Alyx Vance, Gordon searches for a way to free humanity using a variety of weapons, including the object-manipulating gravity gun.Like its predecessor, Half-Life 2 received critical acclaim. It was praised for its advanced physics, animation, sound, AI, graphics, and narrative. The game won 39 "Game of the Year" awards and the title of "Game Of The Decade" at the 2012 Spike Video Game Awards, and is widely considered to be one of the greatest and most important video games of all time. Over 6.5 million copies of Half-Life 2 were sold at retail by December 3, 2008, (not including Steam sales); as of February 9, 2011, Half-Life 2 had sold over 12 million copies.Like its predecessor, Half-Life 2 is a single-player first-person shooter broken into several chapters, permanently casting the player as the protagonist Gordon Freeman. The sequel has nearly the same mechanics as Half-Life, including health-and-weapon systems and periodic physics puzzles, except with the newer Source Engine and improved graphics. The player also starts without items, slowly building up an arsenal over the course of the game. Despite the game's mainly linear nature, much effort was put into making exploration rewarding and interesting; many optional areas can be missed or avoided.A diverse set of enemies is present, which usually require being approached with different tactics: some coordinate in groups to out-maneuver or out-position the player; others, like the Manhack, fly directly at the player through small openings and tight corridors; still others use predictable but powerful attacks, while others hide before swiftly attacking the player. Gordon can kill most enemies with his weapons, or make use of indirect means, exploiting environmental hazards such as explosive pressurized canisters, gas fires or improvised traps. For some portions of the game, Gordon can be joined by up to four armed Resistance soldiers and medics, and can send his team further from him or call them back.Many of the game's new features utilize its detailed physics simulation. Two sections of the game involve driving vehicles. Instead of button-based puzzles from Half-Life, environmental puzzles are also introduced with makeshift mechanical systems, revolving around the player's new ability to pick up, move, and place objects. Solutions involve objects' physical properties, such as shape, weight, and buoyancy. For example, in Chapter 3, Route Kanal, the player is required to stack cinder blocks on a makeshift see-saw ramp to proceed over a wall. Alternatively, the player can use these to build a crude staircase, so sometimes, multiple approaches lead to the desired outcome.Part-way through the game, Gordon acquires the Gravity Gun, which allows him to draw distant objects towards himself or forcefully push them away, as well as the ability to manipulate larger and heavier objects that he cannot manipulate without the weapon. These abilities are required to solve puzzles later in the game, and can also be used to great effect in combat, as any non-static object within proximity to the player has the potential to be used as a makeshift defense (e.g. a file cabinet) or a deadly projectile (e.g. a gasoline can or a buzzsaw blade).The game never separates the player with pre-rendered cutscenes or events; the story proceeds via exposition from other characters and in-world events, and ensures that the player controls Gordon for the entirety of the game. Much of the backstory to the game is simply alluded to, or told through the environment.Half-Life 2 presents a dystopian alternate history of Earth, where the resources of the planet, including the human race itself, are being harvested by an oppressive multidimensional empire, known as the Combine. The game is set around the fictitious City 17, roughly 20 years after the events of its predecessor Half-Life.During Half-Life, the scientists, including Gordon Freeman, at the Black Mesa Research Facility, accidentally caused an inter-dimensional instability known as a resonance cascade and later as the "Black Mesa Incident", when an experiment on an alien crystal sample went wrong.[1] Alien creatures, such as the Vortigaunts and headcrabs, from the borderworld of Xen, flooded into the facility. Gordon fought his way through them and the government cover-up response combat units, making it to the Facility's Lambda Complex. There, the Lambda scientists helped Gordon teleport to Xen, where Gordon destroyed a large alien entity keeping the rift open. Gordon was then suddenly extracted by the mysterious G-Man, who had been watching Gordon over the course of the game. Impressed with his ability to survive against all odds, the G-Man offered him a job before placing him into stasis, which Gordon had no option but to accept.Some time after the ending of Half-Life, the instability at Black Mesa had attracted the attention of the Combine empire, and they invaded Earth. Humanity surrendered at the conclusion of the resulting "Seven Hour War". City 17 became the home of the gigantic Combine Citadel, and Dr. Wallace Breen, the Administrator of Black Mesa who had negotiated the surrender, was appointed representative and Administrator to supervise the survivors on behalf of the Combine.[2] Unable to breed due to a Combine suppression field, humanity matured. The Combine implemented a brutal police state of Civil Protection officers and Overwatch soldiers by recruiting and biologically assimilating humans and other species. Meanwhile, an underground "Lambda Resistance" of humans and Vortigaunts, now working together, was formed. This saw Freeman as a saviour who would lead them to freedom.20 years after the Resonance Cascade, the Combine emerge from the portal with advanced technologies, enabling them to conquer the world in 7 hours. Gordon Freeman is brought out of stasis by the G-Man, who inserts him into a train arriving at City 17.[3] After arriving at the station and eluding Combine forces, Gordon joins Lambda resistance members including Barney Calhoun, a former Black Mesa security guard now working undercover as a Combine CP officer, and Alyx Vance, the daughter of one of Gordon's former colleagues, Dr. Eli Vance. After a failed attempt to teleport to Eli's resistance base known as Black Mesa East from Dr. Kleiner's makeshift laboratory in City 17, Gordon, re-equipped with the HEV suit and a crowbar, is forced to progress on foot through the city's old canal system. After obtaining an airboat, he battles his way to Black Mesa East, several miles from the city.[4][5]Gordon is reintroduced to Eli and meets another resistance scientist, Dr. Judith Mossman.[6] Alyx introduces Gordon to her pet robot D0g and gives him a "gravity gun", an instrument which allows Gordon to easily pick up and move large objects. Black Mesa East comes under Combine attack, and Eli and Mossman are taken to a Combine prison, Nova Prospekt. Separated from Alyx, Gordon takes a detour through the zombie-infested town of Ravenholm with help from its last survivor, Father Grigori. After making his way through the town and a mine, Gordon arrives at a Resistance outpost. He uses a customized dune buggy to travel across a crumbling coastal road to Nova Prospekt.

												Taking place in and around City 17 sometime in the near future, Half-Life 2 follows the scientist Gordon Freeman. Gordon Freeman is thrust into an unfamiliar environment in which the aftermath of the Black Mesa Incident has come to bear fully upon human society. Freeman is forced to battle against increasingly unfavorable odds in order to free Mankind from the Combine. In his struggle, he is joined by various allies, including fellow scientists, rebels, and friends (such as Alyx Vance) - all shocked to see him alive.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Half Life 2 was released in 2004, 6 years after the first one. As i said in my Half Life review, the game revolutionized the FPS genre.https://steamcommunity.com/id/daniel_faraday/recommended/70/It was among the first games to add narrative to its game. To account for the change, it also made the level design very linear. Previously, FPS games would have a very maze like level design.Half Life 2's budget consisted of $40,000,000. I am not sure how much time and money was spent on the source engine itself, but from the development timeline, it seems that source engine was developed from the very 1999, shortly after release of HL1. Why do i want to emphasize of the source engine so much? Well, the main goal of the source engine was to provided realistic physics and facial animations.StoryIn the first game a portal opens up from a planet named Xen. You end up destroying the Queen, thus braking the portal link and ending up in captivity of Gman. The events of Half Life 2 happen 20 years after Half Life 1, somewhere in a eastern Europe town called City 17. Human race got enslaved by Combine, an alien race that was in war with Xen, which got interested in Earth after the events of Half Life 1. Gman decides to send you to City 17 to help the resistance.The realistic facial animations, and graphics in general that source engine provided really add up to the experience. The character really come to life thanks to those facial animations.The faces looked very real unlike say, Max Payne. It really took some time for that technology to appear in mainstream games. Sure, by 2004 there were plenty amount of games that would have a very narrative focus, like Fahrenheit (2005) for PS2. But just imagine how much more immersive it would look if it actually tried to focus on facial animations. Half Life 2 had one of the best facial animation techniques, until LA Noire came out. That game used motion capture.I also felt satisfied with the level the game provided. A zombie town for example. Or a land with arachnid creatures popping out of the sand. The boat chase. Or the one where you have to use the crane to get you car to the other side of the gate. Finally, there is a final chapter with a gravity gun.GameplayHalf Life 2 was the first game to feature physics. Because of that it allowed them to explore new horizons.The game would give the player a gravity gun, which allows you to use objects from the environment to your advantage. You can pick up sharp objects and cut enemies in half with them, or use explosive barrels to lite them up, or simply smash them with something heavy, or even something like tossing back a grenade.There are also new enemy types. New head crabs types were added. They also decided to improve on the zombies aspect of the game and even added a variety of zombie types to the game. There are also arachnid creatures, sort of like ones from Starship Troopers. At one point in the game, you will be able to control them.When you are not fighting these guys, you will be fighting the Combine, who use guns. At times you will also be fighting striders, which are 3 legged machines, sort of like the ones from War of the Worlds. Finally, sometimes you will also be fighting small flying drones. Due to their size, you can actually use the gravity gun. They are also sharp, so you can even cut with them.Thankfully, they decided to dial back on the amount of platforming in this game, though the game had puzzles added, mostly physics related.The game has a total 13 chapters, which is about 15 hours of gameplay.Additionally, it also provides a huge mod library. A lot of my favorites came about by being mods of HL2. Games like Chivalry, Natural Selection, Stanley Parable, Insurgency.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 7
I never understood why Half Life 2 fans loved the game so much.. Until i played it!First ImpressionAt the very beginning I couldn't understand much because it was hell breaking down and there was a lot of running and shooting.. At the same time i couldn't stop emphasizing on how atmospheric the game was. When things calmed down, characters appeared and storyline started making sense.. Amazing!The Beginning(no spoilers)A town that lacks of green, made of worn off buildings with rusty vehicles that don't work anymore. This is the first place we ended up first. Afraid civilians don't talk to each other and remain silent and scattered, while CivilProtection serves and protects the crap out of us all with taser clubs. Men and women dressed in full body suits, speaking through a voice distorter to sound unnatural, became one with the tyrant system just to ensure a better meal.You, Doctor Freeman, try to escape the town, and then it all starts..EnvironmentThe distorted voices of the CivilProtection and the Overwatch Soldiers and the heavily mechanized radio chats/dialogues, the hot deserts and wet sewers, the dark buildings and the empty highways affect the gameplay really heavily. Half Life 2 was the only game that made me forget to blink, thanks to its ability to totally mesmerize me and make me think that i really was out there surrounded by danger!CharactersCharacters are so sophisticated.. They were not made to look pretty (damn these cinematic mods), but their personality and actions earn your admiration and soon after you start to care about their well being.On the other hand, teams of rioted civilians that form around you are not that smart AI and end up serving as meatshields for you to survive, which is sad.WeaponsDespite the real life weapons (TBH crowbars never looked so badass!), there are weapons like Gravity Guns, Pulse Rifles and Bugbait seeds. Bugbait seeds are seeds that help you manipulate and use against the enemies a specified species of monster (Antlions) that would otherwise attack you. Enemies have sniper rifles, but we never got our hands on them.EnemiesWhile the enemy humans are after us, many nightmare fuel monsters turn against us too as we get in their way. The notorious headcrab'ed zombies that slowly hunt us down and the skinny taller ones that run - or even climb - towards us and let out a haunting scream as they jump upon us! The barnacles hanging from the ceilings, the toxic headcrabs and many others make their appearance throughout the game.Stage ProgressingHalf Life 2 is one of those games where there is only one way towards the end of the stage, that is tricky to find out. Moving on requires thinking of ways to move obstacles or to raise gates etc. It won't fit to players who want a game just to kill time. You have to deal with puzzles here!OutroIt's a 10/10 game. I loved it. It is so well made i can't find something to whine about. If you don't have it yet, just get it. If you already have it, play it again!Now.. Where is Half Life 3..?

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												While not as good or as original as the First Half-Life, Half-Life 2 continues the story of Gorden Freeman, following the events of Half-Life. Taking place some time in the future, Gorden must navigate his way though a drastically changed world, encountering old friends and foe's alike. Supplied with a varied array of weaponry and access to mission-critical mounts like the modified buggy, Half-Life 2 offers new challenges and hidden secrets to satisfy lovers of the series. All in all, not a bad game, but not as good as the original.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												This is the source game engine. This game was the bomb when it came out in 2004 and it is still known as one of the best FPS games on the market but this game has a huge bit of history behind it when Valve finished Half-Life 1 they wanted to make a sequel right away but in 2003 after the E3 showcase of the game an ANON German hacker had leaked the files onto the internet and at the time the game was virtually unplayable. This also leaked some CSS BETA content and TF2 ALPHA content but this was one of the biggest thefts at the time and it will stand out in gaming history for a long time and it will always be with the people that have lived through 2003. Finally in 2004 this game was released to the general public with an outstanding physics engine, astonishing shader detail, a jampacked level editor in the files and daziling facial posing NOW can you see why this game is defined as a classic. BECAUSE IT DID SUCH A GOOD JOB AT BEING ONE YA DINGUS. My final rating for this game is a 10/10 since it also has full joystick support BOOM oh and it has GMOD content.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												I think Half Life 2 is a great first person shooter from 2004, with a 9-10 hour single player campaign. There are a wide variety of weapons to use, along with well hidden lambda caches to find and use to your advantege as you battle through City 17 and through the outskirts. However, I don't think Half Life 2 is as amazing as most people claim it to be. "10/10. 11/10. Best game ever!" It kinda makes me laugh... With Half Life 2 being a very solid shooter. I find It difficult to follow the story, or figure out why these events in the game are happening; It feeels like it's out of nowhere. For example: The Combine. They are not in the original Half Life. All that's explained is they are this Inter dimensional organization That wants to enslave Humanity, and you have to fight them. Sequel bait endings are the least of satisfying endings ever, and this game has that.I rate Half Life 2 with a solid 8/10. When this game goes on sale, definitely pick it up. I got the Half Life Collection for about $5.00That's my review for Half Life 2 and I will see you on the next one.     Let's form up! ~Stealth 1548

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												In the spirit of it's predecessor, Half-Life 2 was a groundbreaking FPS at the time it was released.  Most notably was it's use of in-game physics.  Many objects (including enemies) can be used to solve various puzzles and used as weapons throughout this experience.  The actual story is somewhat of an enigma, but the path you are driven to follow and the characters you meet along the way make journey enjoyable nonetheless.  I never experienced the feeling that I was killing enemies simply because I had to progress or the play becoming monotonous.  Each chapter, and indeed the many parts of thereof, was composed of a variety of challenges that were easy enough to pick up but not always as easy to execute.  The only con I can come up with is the squad you get at a point in the game and their inability to stay out of your way at times (especially in narrow hallways D:).    This fast-paced shooter belongs in every action gamer's library. Bravo Valve!

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												After many years I finally completed HL2 and its expansions, and really, it's a game that stands out in the FPS genre.The gameplay is fluid and dynamic, has a satisfactory pace that keeps you stuck to the game and can dose the action sequences with parts that you should play more cautiously, exploring the environment. The AI is a strong point, and although there is little variety of enemies, you don't have a repetitiveness feeling while playing. The Source Engine needs no comments, even after almost 10 years of launching the graphics and physics effects are still convincing. The sound effects are also great.It's in the plot that the game stands out even more, the story is great and is able to keep you immersed in the storyline like few games can, there is a good dose of mystery about some events and some of the most epic and charismatic characters. Gordon Freeman is arguably the most badass and emblematic protagonist of the gaming world, without even saying a single word. The secondary characters are also well-built and charismatic.I highly recommend for those who haven't played. In case of not having played the first and its expansions, is good to seek a source with information about the events prior to this title.9/10

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												More than 9 years old and it's still better than what other FPS games are being churned out today.  Instead of being some elite marine, Gordon Freeman is nothing but a scientist forced to fight for suvival.  And the game plays like that.  Without your Biohazard suit you feel about as useful as any of the other Citizens in the world.Each level is unique and brings around its own gameplay challenges and puzzles.  Do you stop at that house with the smoke comming from it, or continue without stopping?  It's your choice, you are not expected to defeat every single enemy you come across, you can just simply run away.  Not always though.The enemy AI is efficient, even if it may cheat somewhat.  They will advance and use cover, use flanking techniques and move as a squad.  It is let down how it seems to know exactly where you are, even after losing line of sight.  Or perhaps the AI is more intelligent than I'm giving it credit for and can hear my footsteps?  Gordon does sound flat footed at times.The physics engine is still absolutely amazing and well oiled. Need to get over a ledge, but it's too tall?  Good job there is a see-saw next to it, just load the other end with all those bricks lying around to counter balance your weight.  Can't get that draw bridge down, because you are on the wrong side?  No problem, knock it over with that crane.  Ran out of ammo?  Well luckly there is a toilet bowl here and the gravity gun is fully charged.If there is only one thing to gipe about and I do have only the one.  It's the companion AI.  Wait, just here me out.  It starts out fine, with Alyx, just the one.  She get's in your way a bit now and then.  Nothing too annoying, even though she sticks to you like glue and will follow you down every small dead end ally or single exit room.  She will apologize for being in your way, then move away a bit a moment later.  OK, not too much of a problem.  Then you get 4 companions.  All do the same, all stick to you like glue when going down dead end ally ways and block the exit.  The companions can apologise as much about being in the way they as they can, but it will get infuriating at times.  I was evantually glad when a strider wiped them out in a later mission, with no site of reinforcements.Voice acting is tremendous and you also form bonds with the main characters.  Helped along with the facials expressions the engine is capable of.  I don't remember seeing another video game where so much detail can be put through via facial expressions to show the emotions of each character.In closing, Half-Life 2 is a brilliant FPS which hits the right notes in almost every area.  While not a technically impressive as some games released today, the game mechanics are solid and provides an interesting universe and characters to explore.  If you have nether played it, buy it now.  There is no reason to wait for it to go on sale either.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												Ho rigiocato HL2 dopo 10 anni. Ho impiegato 4 giorni a finirlo, contro il mese impiegato 10 anni fa. Questo mi rassicura non poco riguardo alla mia memoria e capacità di apprendimento, evidentemente non ancora del tutto devastate dall'età... Il gioco si presenta ancora molto bene, e quando si inizia è difficile smettere (un po' come con le sigarette). Certo lo stupore provato la prima volta, per la grafica, la fisica e il gameplay oggi non c'è più, ma il divertimento è comunque ancora assicurato. I percorsi obbligati, gli enigmi mai troppo complicati e le ottime possibilità di salvataggio rendono il gioco sempre scorrevole e mai frustrante. L'HDR ha reso la grafica ancora più realistica (per un gioco di 10 anni fa, ovviamente). Un po' lenti i caricamenti, e i salvataggi  causano spesso momentanei inceppamenti, particolarmente fastidiosi a livello audio. Resta in ogni caso un gioco fondamentale, una vera pietra miliare da non perdere assolutamente.I replayed HL2 after 10 years. It took me four days to finish it, against the month took 10 years ago. That reassures me more than a little about my memory and learning ability, apparently not yet completely devastated by age ... The game is still very good, and when you start it is hard to stop (a bit like with cigarettes). Certainly the astonishment felt the first time, for graphics, physics and gameplay today is no more, but the fun is still yet assured. The obligatory paths, the puzzles never too complicated and very good chances of saving make the game always smooth and never frustrating. The HDR made even more realistic graphics (for a ten years old game, of course). A little slow the loadings, and saving often produced momentary jamming, particularly annoying to hear.It is in any case a crucial game, a milestone not to be missed.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												I am your college professor that you requested, with a doctorate in Mathematics. I will break this down as simply as possible and end this debate as approx. 10 students have already asked me this today. The problem as it is written is 6÷2(1+2) , the ÷ cannot be substituted with a fraction bar because they have different ranks on the order of operations. It is an illegal math move to do this. The bar ranks with parentheses, ÷ is interchangeable with *. therefore the problem must be solved as 6÷2(1+2) NOT 6 (over) 2(1+2) we do the parentheses first, so 6÷2(3), the parentheses are now no longer relevant, because the number inside is in it's simplest form. Every single number has implied parentheses around it. 6÷2(3) (6) ÷(2)(3) 6÷2*3, or even converting the division to multiplication by a reciprocal (a legal math move) (6)(1 (over) 2)(3) are all correct ways to write this problem and mean exactly the same thing. Using pemdas, where md and as are interchangeable, we work from left to right, so (3)(3) or 3*3= 9 Just because something is implied rather than written does not give it any special rank in the order of operations.The problem in it's simplest form, with nothing implied would look like this: (1+1+1+1+1+1 (over) 1) ÷ (1+1 (over) 1) * ((1(over) 1) + (1+1 (over) 1)) From here, nothing is implied, This again, works out to 9. If the symbol '/' was used this whole debate would be ambiguous since that symbol can mean "to divide by" or it could mean a fraction bar. HOWEVER, because the ÷ symbol is used, it can not be changed to mean a fraction bar because that would change the order of operations and thus the whole problem, you can't change a symbol to mean something because you want to, in doing so you are changing the problem. Once and for all, the answer is 9. But 9-6=3 thereforeHalf-Life 3 confirmed

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												I recently finished this game, after playing the first one and the expansion packs. I already called Half-Life 1 one of the best games i've ever played, but this one is my all-time favourite.The game is not even nearly perfect, it is perfect. It's action packed, it got GREAT graphics, animations and more for a game from 2004 and it even got moments which were truly epic.Unlike the first one, this one offers more puzzles, greater and more evoirments and more action and even a little bit of horror in it. You not only fight against one enemy, no you get to fight headcrabs, helicopters, City 17 Guards, zombies and more. You kill them on your own creative way around the middle of the game when you get more weapons like the Gravity gun, one of my favourites. It let you travel to so many cool area's and not only on foot.. You get to travel to there with for example a car. Absolutly amazing. It's one of the few games of 2004 that offered so many beatiful content and realistic fighting. For example, around the end of the game, you get to control rebels against City 17, they help you, and give you health if needed. Sure, it got it's bugs, sometimes it also brought me motion sickness.. But that didin't stopped me from playing it.The ending and the mysterious G-Man makes me wanna' play Episode 1, which i surely will. It's only 9 bucks, so if you want to spent that money on a epic journey with enough replay valaue, then go ahead. Buy this game, a game which i think, never gets old and always will stay one of a kind.Great job Valve, this is one of your games to be proud of.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												An amazing game, a must buy, a must play, if you have enough money to buy it then just buy it now.Best way to buy it is through the Orange Box, not just do you get Half-LIfe 2 but also Episode One and Two, plus portal.An action packed game with great moments such as entering the Citadel and getting the Super-Charged Zero Point Energy Field Manipulator, or dashing through Ravenholm. Earth in this time of story has been taken over by Combine forces, but Half-Life isn't one to tell you the story uphand, that can be found with uncovering the deeper story. No time for cut-scences, well there aren't any but that's okay as it keeps you being the Gordon Freeman, it realy does imerse you in the game. Not just comat based based but also Physics too, with some here and there small Physcis puzzles. Later in the game as you progress, gather more weapons and more harder Combine enemies hunt you down you can take control of Antlion insects (something that was once an anoying enemy) and members of the Resistance (People like you who are trying take back Earth and their lives).Throwing and shooting explosive barrels is aways fun.Weapons of Crowbar and Gravity Gun, Glock and Magnum, SMG and Pulse Riffle (both have alt shots), Shotgun and Crossbow, and Grenades and RPG.There are two veichles in which you'll encounter in the game, the Boat and Buggy, personally I never liked the Boat and Water Hazard is one of my least liked chapters in the game, but the Buggy is pretty cool.There are boss battles (if you would call them that) from Hunter-Choppers, Gunships, Striders and Antlion Guards. Over coming these challanges is always an amazing thrill. Each place is always destinctively different and fun.The main problem I have with this game is that even with all this action, a lot of it at times felt a bit samey, but that is dealt with costant upgrade of tools and weapons. Another fault with the game (Both are fixed in Episode One and Two) is that you never seem to stay in one place, always constantly moving from a-b and no c, even though places are memerable.An amazing classic game and experience, with a rich story and lore. I loved it, if this is your first FPS (doesn't count only online ie. Counter Strike or TF2) then thats okay too as it was my first one, more amazingness then flaws, still holding up today in our modern day (Still doesn't have Valve's HDR) gameplay and graphicaly, a game that most FPS inspire too, the amazing, Half-Life 2. You need to play this game.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												An amazing game, a must buy, a must play, if you have enough money to buy it then just buy it now.Best way to buy it is through the Orange Box, not just do you get Half-LIfe 2 but also Episode One and Two, plus portal.An action packed game with great moments such as entering the Citadel and getting the Super-Charged Zero Point Energy Field Manipulator, or dashing through Ravenholm. Earth in this time of story has been taken over by Combine forces, but Half-Life isn't one to tell you the story uphand, that can be found with uncovering the deeper story. No time for cut-scences, well there aren't any but that's okay as it keeps you being the Gordon Freeman, it realy does imerse you in the game. Not just comat based based but also Physics too, with some here and there small Physcis puzzles. Later in the game as you progress, gather more weapons and more harder Combine enemies hunt you down you can take control of Antlion insects (something that was once an anoying enemy) and members of the Resistance (People like you who are trying take back Earth and their lives).Throwing and shooting explosive barrels is aways fun.Weapons of Crowbar and Gravity Gun, Glock and Magnum, SMG and Pulse Riffle (both have alt shots), Shotgun and Crossbow, and Grenades and RPG.There are two veichles in which you'll encounter in the game, the Boat and Buggy, personally I never liked the Boat and Water Hazard is one of my least liked chapters in the game, but the Buggy is pretty cool.There are boss battles (if you would call them that) from Hunter-Choppers, Gunships, Striders and Antlion Guards. Over coming these challanges is always an amazing thrill. Each place is always destinctively different and fun.The main problem I have with this game is that even with all this action, a lot of it at times felt a bit samey, but that is dealt with costant upgrade of tools and weapons. Another fault with the game (Both are fixed in Episode One and Two) is that you never seem to stay in one place, always constantly moving from a-b and no c, even though places are memerable.An amazing classic game and experience, with a rich story and lore. I loved it, if this is your first FPS (doesn't count only online ie. Counter Strike or TF2) then thats okay too as it was my first one, more amazingness then flaws, still holding up today in our modern day (Still doesn't have Valve's HDR) gameplay and graphicaly, a game that most FPS inspire too, the amazing, Half-Life 2. A must have, a must buy. Make sure you also get Episode One and Two (they are expansions), and best way to buy is through the Orange Box.In short words, an amazing Sci-Fi FPS and in all an amazing game, but not as good as it's sequals, amazing. You need to play this game.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												This game is everything that the original game is not.  Indeed, Half-Life 2 is the franchise grown up, and proving that it still has legitimacy in todays gaming world.The story of Half-Life 2 is a bit of a roller coaster in that there are great moments of narrative flow and others where you are left scratching your head a bit thinking "why did they put that in there?".  But saying that, there are plenty of ups to the few downs.  The story is overall strong and immersive with a few deviations that help create a vibrant lore.The game mechanics are obviously much smoother, and well structured.  By todays standards, they stand up.  There are some nice features with the engine that work well.  The feel of the game when using certain weapons and the ability to manipulate some aspects of the environment help the gameplay support the story.  There are still a few things that don't seem right, such as no hands on steering wheels, being able to climb a ladder whilst simulatenously reloading or firing a heavy weapon, getting caught on obstacles, and the clumsy and altogether painful squads that do 2 things - 1) Die over and over, and 2) Get in your way when you need to do a run and gun (or often a grenade lob and duck).  The squad could definitely have used some more commands other than point and press C to have them run uselessly a couple feet before returning to interfere.The weapons pretty much were a joy to use, especially the Pulse Rifle and the SMG.  No alien weapons to use in this game, other than the Antlion Pheropods, and this was the clumsiest weapon.  A few odd decisions were made with some of the weapons though, especially the .357 Magnum revolver.  Having a total ammo store of 18 rounds resulted in this being an often unused weapon.  Surely, Gordon could carry more than 18 bullets for this gun, considering the number he could carry for some of the others like the 9mm with a total ammo store of 168.  I'm sure it was for a balance purpose, but only being able to carry 18 rounds felt silly and frivolous.  The magnum went from being a mainstay weapon of the original series to a bit of a joke weapon in my mind.Of the gameplay, I'm so happy that they decided to move away from the platform styled approach.  Moving across impossible terrain features and engineering in the original games made it feel like a caricature of a game.  Those titles didn't know if they were a shooter, narrative or platformer, often falling more towards the latter.  This game for the most part does away with that completely.  There are still a few gameplay components that aren't well thought out, mainly by being overly long and taking something novel and at first fun, and making it tedius - namely riding the airboat, and crossing the sand without touching it.  Both were fun at first, but quickly devolved into just hoping that it would soon be over, but nope - there was more and more of it.  Still, those didn't detract too much from the game as a whole.The passage of time in the game, like in the first one though, still seems odd.  The immersion of that point is lost easily with the change from night to day as you are constantly on the move, never seeming to rest.... Jack Bauer, eat your heart out.Overall, Half-Life 2 was and still is a great game, and my concerns with the game are more exagerated nitpicks than hangups.4.5/5

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												The second game in the incredible Half Life series.Obviously this game has made VAST improvements over the original. In terms of graphics, gameplay, animations, etc. Not only that but it has a modding community. Now it may not be as grand as Bethesda's modding community. But what THIS particular modding can do uniquely is make fan-base games, and other things from the engine that Half Life 2 runs on. There aren't any real negatives to this game. Sure the vehicle controls are bit iffy when playing on a keyboard. But that's just a nitpick. You can just play this game with a controller. The game is pretty straight forward like the first one. You are 'now' legendary Gordon Freeman. You are thrusted back into the world that you "left behind" to come back and realize the world is different while you've been gone. A new threat has taken over the world and now it's up to you and the Resistance to put an end to the Combine.And of course, the game doesn't really give you everything all at once. It spoon feeds you. So don't expect all the answers to be um...answered! Lol. If you are a fan of the original Half Life. I recommend gettng this.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												A must-have for PC gamers. While Half-Life 1 most certainly hasn't stood against the test of time, Half-Life 2 has aged like fine wine. Even ten years after it's release, the game looks and feels good. Playing as the mute Gordon Freeman, who arrives off the train in City 17, discovers that the city has been taken over by a force only known as the Combine. Shortly after, he meets the protagonists of the game. If I have to make a complaint, it's that none of the characters in Half-Life 2 besides Gordon and the Gman were in Half-Life 1, so you're just supposed to assume that they were there during the Black Mesa incident. To fully understand the story of Half-Life 1, all you have to do is watch the first ten minutes and the last five minutes of the game. I suggest that you skip straight to this one, and if you really want to pick up Half-Life 1 make sure it's less than $5.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2010
												Because you see what happened after Black Mesa, because you want Alyx and because it's the sequel of one of the best FPS in the world.Half-Life 2 is simply set in a world post-Black Mesa, where an entity known as the Combine took control of the Earth, thanks to Dr. Breen, your ex-boss, that negociated the peace. And what peace! Police is brutal, resistance fighters are sent to their death in Nova Prospekt or bombed with Headcrabs missiles, the extinction of mankind is planned as no children can be conceived because of a force field suppressor and Dr. Kleiner, your mentor, has as pet an Headcrab (which is a sort of disaster for your buddy Barney Calhoun.The gameplay is still the same: you shoot, you kill and you try to stay alive between Headcrabs, Antlions and Combine units. And with your arsenal (bazooka, smg, shotgun, crowbar, antlion stuff, crossbow, etc..), you'll be well equipped. The Gravity Gun is also THE new feature: you can take items and throw them or just carry them. And you'll love the Super Gravity Gun at the end of the game.The story will make you visit City 17 before and during the battle for freedom, you'll also take an escape road but very dangerous, see what happens when a town is bombed with missiles, meet a crazy priest, go to the beach, break into a high-security prison and even meet Dr Breen in person. The settings are varied, now that you're outside of Black Mesa and the scientific environement.The new enemies are the Combine Army, kinda replacing the HECU units sent to Black Mesa, but with a better technology, the Antlions, a new alien race, that will be your allies and new types of zombies due to new headcrabs: a faster one and a poisonous one. You can set them in fire too.You'll ride also a buggy and a hydroboat, which is changing from the wagon cart from Black Mesa.Otherwise, the allies will be resistance fighters with their chiefs like Eli, Alyx or Barney, though Alyx will be more your sidekick by moments than Barney. Also, the Vortigaunts, these aliens from Xen with green rays, freed from their enslavement, can assist you and recharge your protection.With the Source Engine, Valve managed to get beautiful graphics but also, good physics, thanks to the Gravity Gun being the new toy for many players.And the soundtrack! It's still marvelous. Still feeling danger or sad moments or adrenaline.Half-Life 2 can be seen as perfect in every aspect... apart the loading time. Or the fact that achievements got implemented at a late date after the release of the Orange Box on Steam (X-box owners had achievements in 2007, PC players got them finally in 2010).Anyway, fun, drama and action are present and Half-Life 2 is really a must-have.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												One of the best FPS games out there! It may be an exaggeration but Half Life 2 remains - even today - one of my favourite games. I believe this game aged well and it looks good even today which marks the 10-year anniversary of this game. Valve later on released some updates to the Source Engine so the game support widescreen and has some extra features to make it look and run better.Story-wise it is an excellent follow-up to the first game as now we have an alien race called Combine who have already invaded and enslaved humanity. Freeman - our numb protagonist - is now tasked with aiding those people who rose up to defy these visitors from space. While some of the creatures we encountered in the first episode return in Half Life 2 you mainly fight against humanoid-like creatures. It's a nice touch and it also showcases the artificial intelligence which is also superb in the game.There are varied environments in the game and there are two things that keep you interested throughout your progress: occasionally you can hop into a vehicle and drive to your next destination. Early on you cannot access this car but you can use a boat to go through a sewers-like stage. The second - and probably best - feature of the game is the Gravity Gun. A gun that does not have ammunition and requires objects - objects in your surroundings that you can pick up and launch at your enemies. There is a level specifically designed for this weapon; a level where ammo is a scarcity and you rely on the precision-aiming skill with the gravity gun.Single-player campaign offers a long (10-15 hour) experience and the game has two expansion packs (the two provide you with roughly 8-9 hours gameplay time). While Episode 1 is a bit of a letdown Episode 2 is an excellent expansion pack.I wish Valve concluded the story of Gordon Freeman with releasing a final episode (Episode 3) or a 3rd sequel. I believe this request - coming from not just me but from the community - is well justified.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2012
												Yes, I would like to start this review by saying that this is my second favorite FPS game. That is not say that it is in the second place because it is almost impossible to choose between Half-Life and Half-Life 2. And that would be unfair as well. These games are from different centuries but both are great, equally great. So what makes is so great? Let's find out... First and foremost I'm absolutely blown away by the story. Maybe not by the story itself but by the way it's told. The first game made me feel in the center of attention and action. It felt like it was very important to complete the mission but without making me feeling some sort of superhero that will win anyway. It may sound strange but I can't better words for it. And it continues here with one of the best intros I have seen in a game. Do you remember how the first game ended? Yes, it ended with a monologue of a man in a blue suit after which you agreed to work for him without really knowing who is working for. This game start with another monologue saying that the time has come for you to unleash all your skills and complete another very tall task. It all feels amazingly tense and even though you're ready to spring into action you are not a superhero so don't expect being handed a machinegun and go around shooting. As I said the narrative is outstanding throughout the game series and it makes it feel very realistic and natural. I don’t want to spoil it for you so I'll let you see it for yourself. What I can tell you though is the way I felt when I started playing. Let's continue then, shall we? So you awake several years after the end of the first part. It is somewhere in the eastern Europe from what I can tell by the architecture, well by what is left from it. The atmosphere is very grim and depressing and you're alone in a unfamiliar city trying to figure out what you need to do and if there are any friends of yours. The first thing you notice are the screens with propaganda and giant tower that you can see from any part of the city. And all of that really put me in the mood to fight. Because clearly someone is controlling the city and most likely the earth.  All of that is backed up by incredible ambient sounds and music. I don't know if it really makes sense to talk about music in this game but if you read review on the original game you'll know that it is something. It follows you around submerges you entirely into everything that is happening around. I first played the game in headphones and that was very wise decision and I'd recommend that to you as well. What kind of atmosphere can be there without proper visuals. And graphics are certainly there. And not just any graphics. Probably the best for the time. For me that is. But considering that it has been more than 10 years since the release of the game you could argue. But if you're into more realistic visuals you can find a mod online that will turn the game into eyecandy. So this game has amazing sounds, graphics and story. How does it play then. Well, it pays absolutely fantastic. It is a true sequel and it carried over everything that made the original such a great game. Suit is there, crowbar is there, awesome guns are there to accompany dynamic and fast-paced shooting action. Even if you're not shooting you can still feel the adrenaline. Guns are fantastic to use, blasting through the enemies. And there's variety of enemies ranging from headcrabs to helicopters and giant striders. All of them have very good AI and they never made me feel an overpowered protagonist putting down handicapped enemies. It's complete opposite because I found myself many times low on ammo and low on health hearing suit AI saying "User death imminent". What Half-Life never lacked are the unusual weapons and you'll some this time as well. For example Pulse Rifle which is my favorite and something very special - Gravity Gun. The latter really helps to get out of sticky situations when you're low on ammo or being overpowered by zombies. It has so many uses and every time I figured out something new I felt real scientist. By the way this time you're not doing everything alone. You have friends that will aid in the battle. I would characterize their AI as limited but sometimes they are really helpful. In my opinion their role is to make you feel as a part of Resistance more than anything else. And they certainly succeed at that. You will come across quite a few puzzles. What would Half-Life game be without puzzles. They are not that hard but require you to see the big picture. Gordon Freeman went to MIT so those puzzles should be not a problem.  As with the original game I played Half-Life 2 more than once. I played few times just didn't feel like playing something else and then I played it once again to unlock every single achievement and then I played it prior to Episode One and Two to refresh memories This game is definitely worth picking up even though it's more than 10 years old but it still has that tense, action packed gameplay, immersive music and graphics that hold up today in my opinion.More reviews from Gameaways Curator

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												This game is very successful to begin with so there isn't much to say I guess. It's a classic among the FPS genre. Featuring the source engine which was amazing at the time this game has been mind blowing.        The gameplay is very simple just like in the previous game and there's plenty of action to go on, besides that there are puzzles that come along the way. The arsenal ranges from a crowbar to a smart rocket launcher and other alien technology. There is one heroine that accompanies Gordon for a good part of the game. There's at least 20 hours of gameplay in the game without episode 1 and 2.       The story revolves around Dr. Gordon Freeman who used to work in the Black Mesa research institute and he is one of the survivors from the incident that had a major roll in the invasion of the Combine that occured afterwards. He is hired by an individual with mysterious abilities, the motives of this person are unknown to Gordon. From here on Gordon is placed in City 17 and he begins his struggle against the Combine.      The graphics and the mechanics of the game are very good to date and bug free.      The soundtrack is pretty fitting if I may say so myself.       The only issue regarding the game would be the stupidity of the NPC's and possibly the lack of harder difficulty choices and the the changes between them are minor. If you haven't played the first game, you should give it a try.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												I still think this is the best FPS out there. It's single player, yes, but for many of us who enjoy a good story and mechanics over multiplayer features, this games, on this genre, has no equal. Gonna make this review short, as I don't think I can add much more to what is already known.Graphics and AI are old, sure. But still looking great compared to some games nowadays. But the main focus of this review is the story behind the game. The lore. The map designs. Everything is so well done that you almost feel it's a movie and not a game. If you like FPS, this game is a must. My recommendation, however, is to first play HL1. Then get this one

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												Half-Life 2 is the long awaited sequel to the original Half-Life game and makes it's unique mark as quite possibly be one of the greatest game or greatest FPS game ever created. Half-Life 2 was created using the Source engine which runs flawlessly with gorgeous visual, physics interaction, and smooth gameplay. Half-Life 2 improves upon every single aspect of the original game including a longer and more solid story and campaign. The best thing about Half-Life 2 is the Gravity gun, which allows you to pick up and throw any object - making even a toilet a deadly weapon! If you only play one FPS game in your life, the choice is simple: Half-Life 2.

												awww what can i say about the legendary Half-Life 2 that hasnt been said already?maybe i could mention the unmatched pacing of the game with amazing memorable chapters like "Point Insertion" and "We Don't Go To Ravenholm..."i could talk about the excellent physics-based puzzle design, which is extremely intuitive yet challenging and satisfyingi could also mention the fantastic gunplay and weapon variety, many of which have a secondary fire to spice things up, and includes the all-time favorite Gravity gun which lets you abuse the physics engine in highly amusing waysand i could never go on without describing how the game seamlessly combines gameplay and storytelling, never taking control away from the player just to barf exposition into your faceand how could i even forget to mention the excellent cast of likeable characters that populate this grim futuristic dystopia, brought to life by some of the best voice acting there isi might as well mention this is my favorite FPS ever, my 3rd overall favorite game of all time and the fact this game is just as good today as it was almost 10 years agobut all that has probably been said before, so ill just go and say that the "Anticitizen One" chapter was very disappointing, thats pretty much the only fault the game has

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												First and foremost, Half-Life 2 is a stunning game. While I try not to hype it too much, it may be hard to do the experience justice. I have played through it at least six times, and it is still fun to get to those edge-of-your-seat moments when you may know what is going to happen, but you still need to push to make it to that point. Half-Life 2 is an amazing sequel to what has to be one of the finest games of all time. The series is very well made, the story is extremely well written, and the gameplay is nothing short of breathtaking and very animated. Playing as Dr. Gordon Freeman and seeing through his eyes is truely a spectacle to behold. There are so many interesting plot twists and delicious high-tension moments, that the only way to truely experience them is to play the game. I guarantee, once you play you will know why so many people have absolutely fallen in love with the series, and can not wait to see it continue.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												All hail the crowbar!This is the game that got me hooked on shooters. In that respect I guess it has a lot to answer for! And, along with Episodes 1 and 2, it remains my favourite to this day. Valve have taken their 1998 classic Half-Life and improved on it in every conceivable way. Much improved graphics, much improved physics, much improved AI, and much improved weapons, most notably the wondrous gravity gun. Once again it mixes a wide variety of spectacular environments with some satisfying puzzles and some fantastic combat. It also develops the story started in the original and fleshes it out nicely. Another important gain is the introduction of Alyx and her father Ely. Alyx will be a welcome companion and will, periodically, fight by your side. This is a big factor in HL2 -- the introduction of team play. You will have small bands of resistance fighters with you sporadically during play in the single player mode and this adds a team element which greatly increases immersion and the sense that what you do matters. I could bang on about this game for ever and a day, but just let me say this: play it -- you won’t regret it.5/5

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												You know, there's a reason this game won 39 Game of the Year awards, and Game of the Decade.It's GOOD. No wait, it isn't. It's not great either.It's an absolute masterpiece. It's got great and exciting gameplay, an engrossing storyline, characters you'll come to love, graphics that still look great to this day (to me at least, I've always liked the Source Engine), physics that are fun to mess around with, AI that would make GLaDOS cringe (okay, not really), an awesome soundtrack, developer commentary for those of you who like to listen to it....And a Gravity Gun.That, combined with the nostalgic value this game has to me, is why this game will always remain in my heart as my favorite video game of all time. Very highly recommended.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2013
												Valve set a standard with the first Half Life, and this one raises the bar. You can tell a landmark has occurred when most of what comes after is derivative in some way. The worst part of playing a game this good is being unable to enjoy mediocre titles without feeling let down. A good sign of an underperforming developer is when they react to being compared to games like this with the phrase 'gamer entitlement'. If you only play games with friends, download the Synergy mod available on Steam.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												You know, there's a reason this game won 39 Game of the Year awards, and Game of the Decade.It's GOOD. No wait, it isn't. It's not great either.It's an absolute masterpiece. It's got great and exciting gameplay, an engrossing storyline, characters you'll come to love, graphics that still look great to this day (to me at least, I've always liked the Source Engine), physics that are fun to mess around with, AI that would make GLaDOS cringe (okay, not really), an awesome soundtrack, developer commentary for those of you who like to listen to it....And a Gravity Gun.That, combined with the nostalgic value this game has to me, is why this game will always remain in my heart as my favorite video game of all time. Very highly recommended.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												HALF LIFE 2 REVIEWHalf Life 2 is the first FPS I ever played. I remember when I bought the Orange Box on PS3 I was just amazed! 5 years later replaying it on PC it just adds to the amazing quality of the game. I loved every single second of it and is one my most favorite games of all time. Half Life 2 is a tense, thrilling, and all around amazing game that should be played by everyone.NOT FOR: People who don't like FPS's. I would still recommend trying it out, but if that's not really your thing, I don't think Half Life 2 would change your mind all that much. However keep in mind that this is more of an old school first person shooter, unlike say Call of Duty. This game doesn't tell you where to go or how to get there, maybe not as much as the original Half-Life, but still a far cry from the crazy hand holding a lot of modern games have today.FOR: People who want to play or try out a different stlye of FPS. This is not Call of Duty. No constant checkpoints or arrows showing you where to go. While this may prove frustrating for some...(It was for me the first time I tried it.) It proves to be extremely rewarding. On a other note this game doesn't have regenerating health which up's the challenge factor considerably. Even on easy you can every easily die if you don't react fast enough. IN CONCLUSION: I hope this review finds you well and if you want some other games like Half Life 2, make sure to get it's sequels Episode 1 & 2 . Also try out Portal and Portal 2 as they are in the same universe. (The Portal series is a puzzle game so it's different, but it's in the same story universe.)  Lastly play the originaly it'll be worth it.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												What is there to say about Half-Life 2? Saying it was good, would be a waste of the entire internets time. So here's a more detailed description: This is a game that is still generaly better than most games made from 2012 onward. I never was a full PC gamer untill around 2010, and by then I played most triple A games that were available to me on console. Half-Life2 is a great game even if you like most generic money grabbing piles of♥♥♥♥♥♥ This game has something for just about everybody. If you like a good FPS, this is your game. If you like a good horror game, this is your game. If you want a puzzle game, this is the game for you. This game was made in 2006, and was around 6 years ahead of its time. The physics engine does its job and there's enough things that either fly out at you in the dark, shoot at you for not "picking up that can" (:D) and areas of the game that require skill and stratergy. Not so less that its to easy, and not so much to feel impossible. The story line of this game is overall entertaining and great. If you want to know who Gordon Freeman (the primary protagonist) is, here's a quick rundown: Gordon Freeman is a silent protagonist, wait come back, here's where it gets interesting. The involment of the game is dependant on the player entirely! During the start of game, you could be a guy, who has been sent into the furutre to kill John Conne- I mean, Alyx Vance. The dialog is enough to envolve you but not so much that you feel like the massive hero who immortal! No. The game's story revolves around who the player wants Gordon Freeman to be, thus creating the best video game character who ever existed, because of vanity reasons. So lets get onto graphics, 2006 THE END. No just kidding, Being a PC gamer faced with Alpha's and other games who dont have great graphics so they dont matter to me. They're good enough to see what you have to kill and who you are, also: NOT USING THE SAME (BLEEP)ING TEXTURE ON WALLS MAKING (BLEEP) CONFUSING! Anyway, my overall review score is 96/100 (same meta-score but then again the only game to get 100/100 in my opinion is Portal, so yeah)

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
 "By taking the suspense, challenge and visceral charge of the original, and adding startling new realism and responsiveness, Half-Life 2 opens the door to a world where the player's presence affects everything around him, from the physical environment to the behaviors even the emotions of both friends and enemies."  Story  Half-Life 2 is the direct sequel to the award-winning original, Half-Life, released on Nov. 16, 2004. The story continues the adventures of past-Black Mesa researcher and scientist, Gordon Freeman. After being put in stasis by G-Man after the Black Mesa incident, Gordon is sent out again almost 20 years after the event, greeted by the barren, desolate, and oppressed world that is planet Earth. The event that was the Resonance Cascade, which opened up a portal from Xen to Earth, allowed the creatures from Xen to flood in, killing scientists and marines alike. The aliens of Xen were followed by a greater, even more powerful race, called the Combine, who started and ended the Seven-Hour war, declaring the creatures of Xen and humans of Earth as their own. They took control of the Earth, and started funnleing out a never-ending stream of soldiers, who beat down and controlled the human populace. When Gordon steps out of stasis, he joins the Resistance, a human and alien force who constantly battle the Combine to once again free the Earth.  Gameplay  Half-Life 2's Gameplay is centered around the use of weapons in combat, as in the original. Yet, as not seen before, you are now given the oppurtunity to explore your surrondings completely, finding tucked-away areas and hide-aways brimming with secrets and discoveries. The game is set in a first-person view, with your character, Gordon Freeman, not talking or reacting to the enviroment in any verbal way. This gives You, the player, complete immersion and focus, letting you feel, see, think, and do exactly how you want and the way you want. Valve, the creators of the Half-Life series, have created one of the best realistic-physics engine to date, the Source engine. This means that any and all items, vehicles, furniture, materials, weapons, creatures and people will react to the enviroment realistically, such as weight, visibility, health, and more. There are many weapons to use, such as the SMG, Rocket Launcher, and brand-new Gravity Gun. The Gravity Gun can pick up objects in the game, even the heavier ones like barrels and dressers. You can use the Gravity Gun to pick up objects out of the way, punt them great distances, and use them as blunt weapons when thrown. And, yes, the crowbar is back, which can be used for breaking obstacles and killing enemies.  Graphics  The Graphics of Half-Life 2 are made by Valve's game engine, Source. With this, the enviroment can look fresher then ever, with swaying grass and rope, white clouds and bright suns, and shiny, polished floors, and rough, cut wood. The graphics of Half-Life 2 are not, in any way, a showcase of today's games, but do feel surprsingly realistic and crisp, and look quite good even after all these years.  Overview  Half-Life 2 is a masterpiece of a game, winning over 39 Game of the Year awards, among others, and is widely considered to be the best game of all time. The characters are unique and quirky, like rebelious Alex, nervous Dr. Kleiner, and confident Eli. The enviroments range from city streets, to zombie-infested rooftops, to a Combine-controlled prsion. Weapons are powerful but require precision and focus, battles are challenging but have to be examined and tactically played, and the enviroment is breath-taking but deadly and dangerous. This is the kind of game every person should play at least once, from indie-game casuals to multiplayer tryhards. So, put on your H.E.V. suit, grab your trusty crowbar, and become The One Free Man.
