content:
Posted: December 26, 2012
												Edit: 11/23/16- Nominated this game for the Steam Awards: Test of Time Award***I WROTE THIS REVIEW IN 2007... Found it on my HD and reposted it because I felt it still holds up- hope you enjoy it***Arguably the most anticipated sequel to a video game ever, Half-Life 2 has had fans itching to play it since its proposed development in 1999 after the huge success of its predecessor Half-Life. Over those five years, Valve, had promised amazing advances in videogame features such as in game physics, graphics and enemy and cooperative AI (artificial intelligence). Having played Half-Life 2 multiple times and continue to jump on and play almost two years after its release, I can honestly say it is still the best FPS I have ever played.You again assume the role as Dr. Gordon Freeman. After having accepted the G-man's proposal to work for him at the end of Half-Life, the introduction to Half-Life 2 has Gordon once again arriving on a train to work to City 17; a city that resembles a rundown poor neighborhood that is well guarded by soldiers known as the Combine. As you walk through the streets and notice the fortress walls and strict enforced laws, you begin to see a few familiar faces such as Barney, the security guard from Half-Life and Half-Life: Blue Shift, Dr. Kleiner and Dr. Mossman. A new character, Alyx is introduced as Mossman’s daughter. Alyx brings Gordon to a secret lab where the Dr. Mossman has been working on a teleportation device that would transfer Gordon to Black Mesa East - another lab a considerable distance outside of City 17. You also receive another familiar item and as well as some comforting familiar music. As you can imagine, something goes wrong during the teleportation process and Gordon is teleported outside of the lab where the Combine discovers him. Gordon must now once again fight his way through enemies to save the planet from the invading army.Gameplay:It is virtually impossible to create a non-linear FPS single player game. Games need to be scripted and one directional for the player to receive objectives on how to proceed to the next level. It is the brilliant writing and level design in what makes Half-Life 2 give players a sense of freedom. Half-Life 2 continues right where Half-Life left off in terms of gameplay. You continue your story from Gordon's perspective, there are no cut scenes or narration moments that interrupt the game. Levels are still in episode form, allowing short loading times and weapons and health upgrades are not glowing, spinning or floating in mid air, but yet realistically places on tables, cabinets, or mounted on walls.Instead of inserting a FMV directly into the game, Half-Life 2 uses its own cinematic vision by just creating fully interactive events directly into the game; Missiles launched at a towering smokestack that crumbles at the base and begins to topple over onto a river, Strider's demolish a building or alien monsters crashing through walls and up from the ground. HL2's style of gameplay changes as you progress. For example, Doom 3's gameplay is same: walk cautiously through each hallway in fear of a demon hiding in a shadow or Painkiller's gameplay is run around shooting stuff for all eternity. HL2 actually takes a considerable amount of time for Gordon to actually start blasting away the Combine, and even when you finally receive weapons, you are running through the sewer system trying to keep a low profile. Gordon finally gets help from some fellow rebel soldiers and is given a hovercraft that he uses to travel future outside of City 17 but continuing to solve puzzles to advance over obstacles and Combine controlled checkpoints. Gordon does experience some fierce resistance during his time on the hovercraft, but if successful you will reach a point where Gordon can take a break from fighting. The point: HL2 shadows the timeline of a real movie, starting off slow while rising to a pinnacle fight scenes while every once in a while changing the style of the game to give the player a psychological break. This is a HUGE subliminal feature that causes players to become so attached to the stories in the game, instead of turning into a mindless shooter like so many other games.Gordon's arsenal of weaponry is similar from the first game. You start off once again with only a crow bar, which is satire in itself as Barney drops the crowbar off the roof of a building claiming "hey Gordon, I think you left something back at Black Mesa." You eventually go through the standard weapon progression, gaining a handgun, machine gun, an advanced Combine assault gun, crossbow- which shoots hot metal rods at enemies allowing you to staple them to the side of walls as their bodies hang limp.Graphics and Sounds:We now can now check off 'exciting unique story' on our "What makes an Amazing Game?" list and proceed to the most impressive feature of HL2. If you were keeping track of HL2 since its proposed development, you may remember a demonstration video that outlines what the engine in HL2 is capable of. The demo featured the Source engine and walked through some of the more common elements that would be present in the game: fire looks like fire, water refracts light, wood breaks like wood and the overall life like adjustments of things falling caused by gravity. The demo was just the beginning.Half-Life 2's level (or chapter) design is so life like (even today), you forget the game is as linear as any other FPS; that there really is only one path to take but the levels fools players into thinking there are hundreds. Wide-open courtyards, rivers, fields really help players sink into the gaming environment. Gordon's journey takes him through the daylight, dusk, night, dawn, underground tunnels, sewers, abandoned houses, coastlines, and the infamous Citadel. There is no other single player game that changes surroundings as much as Half-Life 2. Doom 3 will always be on Mars and F.E.A.R. will always be played at night.Smaller graphical features are also impressive like the refraction of light through water, the colors of the sky reflecting on top of water, life like facial movements, explosions, it will all make you stop and admire. To coincide with the strong visuals are impressive audio effects. The sharks puncture of gunshots is excepted in most games that contains weapons, but actually simulating the ricochet of guns and bombs is phenomenal. Bombs dropped by helicopters will explode with a sharp explosion and seconds later you will hear the delayed echo of the bomb. The same idea happens over the course of the game and as the scenery changes so does the effects of the sound. Inside canals, sewers or traveling over a river or inside a building and hearing the same explosions is defined as adjusting your home stereo to “hall” or “Cathedral”. If you happen to purchase the complete package through steam, you are sent a copy of the Half-Life 2 soundtrack, which has lived up to its own name from the first game. Usually the game is played in silence, but certain chapters will open with a theme that is appropriate with the environment.Muliplayer:Half-Life 2: Deathmatch is exactly how it sounds. Pick your character and run around several different multiplayer maps killed each other with different weapons that can be found in HL2 the game. What makes the game fun and interesting is you also come equipped with the gravity gun, which you can use to throw couches, and rocks at opposing players.Pros: life like physics engine, nexgen graphics, multiple multiplayer mods,Cons: mediocre AI not as impressive as hyped to be, a lot of material cut out of final releaseBottom Line: A MUST play for all gamers. Half-Life 2 continues to impress players as the game progresses showing off its unprecedented physics and graphics engine. This story will hook you in, the graphics will make your eyes water and the overall game will completely blow you away.

Posted: December 6, 2013
												You know, there's a reason this game won 39 Game of the Year awards, and Game of the Decade.It's GOOD. No wait, it isn't. It's not great either.It's an absolute masterpiece. It's got great and exciting gameplay, an engrossing storyline, characters you'll come to love, graphics that still look great to this day (to me at least, I've always liked the Source Engine), physics that are fun to mess around with, AI that would make GLaDOS cringe (okay, not really), an awesome soundtrack, developer commentary for those of you who like to listen to it....And a Gravity Gun.That, combined with the nostalgic value this game has to me, is why this game will always remain in my heart as my favorite video game of all time. Very highly recommended.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Welp... Half Life 2. We meet again. What could you say about this gem that hasn't been said before? OH WeL Of corsE YOu neEd iT FUR GmoD!!11!!No... I didn't mean that... I'm talking about Half Life 2 here... not Source.Half Life 2 is, simply put, top notch. Seriously, if you haven't played Half Life 2 at least until Ravenholm (Grrrrrrrrrrr) SHAME ON YOU! I don't wanna spoil the story or the famous characters to those Steam newbies out there who were told to get Half Life 2 just for Gmod, so I'll say... PLEASE play Half Life 1 before playing Half Life 2. Half Life 2 is THE BEST Half Life game. I'm sorry, but the episodes, even with being fantastic, I couldn't help but feel REALLY empty at the intro of Episode One. Oh wait... Sorry, wrong game... AAaanyway, Even if it's not on Steam, even if it's pirated, just play it. It'll bring a lot of nostalgia (and by nostalgia I mean 3 days ago when you FINISHED Half Life 1) with the occasional funny joke, famous boss fight, and that stuffs. Me being a personal die-hard Half Life fan (profile pic), I'd recommend Half Life 2 to anyone. I'm proud and not afraid to say that Half Life 2 is one of the best, if not THE best Valve game ever made. Sure, the Source 1 (GoldSource counting as Source 0 as I call it) engine is REALLY coming of age [L4D(2), CS:GO, Portal 2], and SOME of the voice acting could have been better, but for the time... 2004... 10 friggin years ago, this game looked like Battlefield 4 back then! Half Life 2 is a game that may truly make you bow down to the One Free Man forever more. Id recommend Half Life 2 to anyone who is willing to... well... let's say it how Breen would say it...To be wise. Be safe.Be aware.11/10. And proud of it. *Bows down to the One Free GabeN*

content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
												Although Half-Life 2 has somewhat changed from Half-Life 1 when it comes to design, the innovations it brought with the new Source Engine (which is still used up to this day) were amazing for that year. The mimics and so much of possibility that a person even created Garry's Mod for children and adults alike to have fun.The game itself is amazing. - The plot needs to be understood via HL wikipedia, not only by the game itself. Once you understand the plot, you realize how realistic an alien invasion can get and how it might look like.- The graphics were great for that year, you cannot compare them with the new games now as the engine is outdated.- The gameplay is very Quake-ish, which does break the immersion, but mods can somehow add the 'realistic combat' feel. This quake-ish gameplay is positive on one hand and negative on the other. You have to see it for yourself.- Voice acting is amazing and professional.- The physics are amazing when it comes to the Source engine usage of Havok.- The leveldesign is made in a way that it will never frustrate you, nor bore you, which feels like a genius made it, sometimes you have to use logic in order to advance.Overall score in the year 2004: 10/10 Overall score in the year 2016: 10/10I have this fetish of realistic gameplay ever since I played games like Red Orchestra 2, so I do hope that Half-Life 2 will get remastered and designed in a way that would allow us to play it not in a Quake style, but rather in 'realistic shooter' style, in order to give it the true feel of fighting off the enslaving alien regime throughout the blocs and apartments.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												Half-Life 2 is a game that, once you play, you will never forget.i can say wholeheartedly that this game is one of the best, if not THE best, i have ever played in my entire life.why?lets take it from the top.the game begins with a short cutscene, a monolouge by a man in the suit (dubbed, the Gman), which at the begining of the game doesn't make a whole lot of sense, but the farther you go into it, the more it will make sense to you. i should state here that knowledge of the previous game in the series (Half-life) is not required, but i will say that it is reccomended, as this games story will make more sense, as well as some of the throwbacks this game gives to its predecessor. as the Gman speaks, different locations flash on the screen, that add to the mysterious nature of this intro. Who is the Gman? Where are these places? What is he talking about? before you have time to ponder these questions, a loud horn interrupts you, as you are thrown straight into the game. you take a short monorail ride into City 17, and the game exhibits its art direction very well in this first section taking place in City 17. After events transpire, you are thrown into the action yet again, this time by yourself and only a crowbar to defend yourself. this is where the game introduces its combat system, and let me take this moment to say that this is one of the reasons i love this game. instead of showing you annoying tooltips that pop onto the screen, obscuring your vision, the game instead has you learn from experience how to use weapons. this game has a very old school feel to its combat system, and i really cant stress enough how good the combat feels and how precise it can be at times. over time, the story has you travelling to many different, beautiful looking locations (for a game from 2004, the graphical fidelity stands up surpisingly well, and at times looks better than many games being released nowadays) battling more intimidating foes as you go on. this can create some truly amazing moments in the story, such as when you battle a helicopter using an airboat with a machine gun mounted on the top of it. the sound design is good too, the music is never annoying, and the gun sounds never get on your nerves after hearing them thousands of times. in wanting to not spoil the game for those who have not played it, let me say that there are some truly emotional moments in the game, as well as some clever twists and turns placed here and there.let me end this review off with saying that, if you have not played Half-Life 2 yet, please do yourself a huge favor and purchase this game. you will not regret your decision one bit. it has truly changed the way i view games.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												This is what happens when a perfect combination of narrative, level design, gameplay and interactivity meet. Not to mention the (at the time) mind blowing graphics. This is, in my opinion, the pinnacle of all of Valve's work and truly one of the greatest games I've played as of yet. It simply does everything right- the story keeps you immersed and the characters are all memorable, with dialogue and cinematics being one of the most interesting parts of the game, other than being just a break from combat (which happens all too often nowadays). The gunplay feels just right, and every weapon in your ever-increasing arsenal is great in its own way- different situations will call for different weapons. The gravity gun deserves mentioning though, as it is just pure awesome and allows you to truly use your environment to your advantage (hurling explosive barrels, slicing through enemies with sawlades, throwing enemy grenades back, etc.). There are also no cutscenes- every single event takes place through the eyes of Mr. Freeman, which is an approach that Valve absolutely nailed. As I mentioned before, the game continuously encourages environment interaction, and not just with the gravity gun. The clever puzzles throughout the game are an example of this. The enemy variety and artificial intelligence is also incredible. All in all, an amazing game. And, as a side note, WE WANT A SEQUEL ALREADY!!!!

												If you could only play one game in your entire existence on this Earth then play this game. It is a work of pure perfection and I believe you have not lived if you haven't played it. Half-Life 2 is a signal player, FPS, action, sci-fi game. It came out in 2004 yet is still an experience no other video game developer has been able to replicate. I find it amazing how this game doesn't have cutscenes or tells you what to do next. I strongly urge anyone who has not played this to buy it right now and play it immediantely. Then buy episodes 1 and 2. Then cry over the non-existence of Half-Life 3.Warning: Watch out for those head-humpers.

												Well...The graphics are pretty good for a game that was made in 2004. And the updated has even better graphics. The story line,Characters and their storyline,Our storyline are all good, So in this game you are playing as Gordan Freeman a scentist from Black Mesa Facality. He made a test but failed and got all Xen Monsters to the real world (Xen is another dimension full of ohter creatures...Most are dangerous) So as gordan tries to escape by finding weapons from people who died. He later on met a mysterious character reffered to (Gman) Some say he is god while ohters say he is A goverment. But who knows. So Gordan meets this character and this character wants Gordan to be his (Employee) Oh and here is some information about him (Gman is neither a bad or good character. Sometimes he helps you while ohetr times he makes it harder for you he is a mysterious character and no one actually knows his actual name its just because in the files gmans files is  called "G_Man") So Gman leaves and Gordan gets teleported to where he was. I dont remember mutch more. But this is just a feedback not an entire story. So i rate 10/10 Because the storyline and characters and weapons are all just perfect im sure you should igve this game a try. But i suggest trying playing the demo. If you like the demo you should buy the game :) It is worth the money. There is a mod too called "Synergy" This mod lets you play Half life online..Any kinda half life game and is 100% free as long as you have atleats one hl game..You will only be able to play the HL Games in synergy you ahve already bought You need Atleast one of the HL Games from the series to actually play Synergy You can chose from Half life 2, Half Life 2 ep 1, Half Life 2 ep 2 Thats all i know you can use but yeah i suggest you play this game. I really enjoyed this game. And im sure you're gonna enjoy it too! Here is the link for synergy download  rememebr it is absolutely free as long as you have bought atleats one of these games Half Life 2, Half life 2 ep 1, Half Life 2 ep 2 if you havent you will not be able to play Half Life 2 online

content:
Posted: September 6, 2013
												Half-Life 2 is one, if not the best, first person shooter to hit the market. The only game to could top this is the first Half-Life, for reason you should know. This game has changed the way I look at games from now 'till the end of times. • The storyline is really good and makes me want to keep playing so I could see what crazy things Gordon has to do.• The soundtrack is a really good addition to this game. It just makes the entire game seem more whole. Without it I dont know how I would have been able to tell what pace the game was going in.• The graphics are really good because it marked the path for future Valve games like: Portal, Life 4 Dead, and Team Fortress 2. All of those games have been ground breakers themsleves.Over all I would highly recommend that you get this game I know you wont regret it.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Sequel of one of the highest acclaimed games of all time. Half-Life continues the story of Gordon Freeman as he is woken up only to find that Earth has been taken over by an alien empire - the Combine. Throughout the game, he gets help from human resistance and former allies from Black Mesa. Puzzles are pretty much kept at the first installation's style, though I found them to be way easier. In Half-Life 2, there are more vehicles - an airboat and a buggy are added and they provide some more refreshing gameplay where you drive with them and ocassionally have to stop in order to solve a puzzle, because the path is blocked.Game features more weapons, most importantly - the gravity gun. I guess it shows the psychics of the source engine, but its a pretty fun weapon to use, some areas can be cleared without using any firearms. Near the end of the game it becomes even better and more powerful.Obviously, it has better graphics than Half-Life 1.For those that liked the first game - this is a must buy. I guess you can still play it as your first game from the franchise, but it just isn't the same in my opinion.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												THIS IS MY OPINION IF YOU DO NOT AGREE THAT IS OK!!!!half life 2 has some of the best reviews I have seen. I am fairly new to pc gaming therefore I never played this game when it was new so there is no nostalgia in here. The first thing i thought when i started playing this game was: wow these graphics are good for a game that's like, 10 years old!! my second impression was: man those combine dudes are jerks. That is one of the coolest things about half life 2. from the very starting  of the game it builds up your resentment for the combine, your main enemies throughout the game unlike some other shooter which just throw you in and say: shoot these guys. The biggest low point in the game is the vehicle sections. at first it's kinda like wupeee!! im in a boat or a car or whatever but the vehicle levels for me were long and boring.another thing about half life 2 that really is cool is the gravity gun. and while i wont spoil anthing i will tell you it is fun to use against some particular enemies. despite how old the engine is the physics are actually not that bad althougth it does sometimes glitch out when you use vehicles. (I once sent a car flying across the map when i dropped it wth a crane.) One thing that is especially amusing to watch is the combine's bodies crumple when thay are shot with a shotgun or magnum. the games music is very very bad. it sounds sci fi and techno sort of which ruins the atmosphere. the other sound however are superb.the story is pretty hard to understand if you havent played the original by the way. you may want to read something online if you absolutely must understand it.one of the high points in half life 2 is the puzzles. you don't see many shooters that use puzzles in them which is strange considering how good of reviews this game got. one example is stacking blocks on the end of a wooden plank to be able to jump to a ledge.  Bet you have never seen that in a call of duty game! here are my reviews overall. graded out of 10graphics:  8.0Story: 7.0gameplay: 8.5Level design: 9.0music: 6.5this is a superb sci fi shooter dampened only by tedious vehicle levels and a bad soundtrack                                                                      OVERALL 9.0

												Starting off a game like Half-Life 2 is the beginning to an adventure -and most importantly, to one of the best experiences that anyone will ever have when playing a Valve game. HL2 is the immaculate embodiment of what Valve is and stands for; it's the quintessential staple to the constituents of a modern First Person Shooter.However, parts of this game have not aged well to this day - it makes things rather difficult and odd. But, that doesn't worsen the experience by one bit - so long as you appreciate this game for what it is.[10/10]

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
For better or worse, HL1 and HL2 popularised linear, guided FPS games. HL2 also popularised physics as a gameplay element.I've played through this game so many times now, but I'll try to remember my first impressions from back when it came out.What I enjoyedBeing very impressed at the facial animations when Alyx leans over you that first time.Spending hours messing around with the console, spawning enemies and making them fight each other, and throwing rollermines at them with the gravity gun.Replaying Ravenholm over and over because it's like a physics playground with all the zombies and circular saws and explosive barrels... and the gravity gun.Did I mention how mind-blowing the gravity gun was that first time I used it?Loving the cast of characters. Alyx, Isaac Kleiner, Eli, Dr Breen...Approaching the Citadel little by little, that looming towering structure, until you finally reach it and enter it, genuinely unsettling... and appreciating the design decisions all the while.The music, sparingly used, perfectly setting the mood. Some of the tracks are etched in my mind, like the one at the end of Ravenholm.Playing this game again and again.What I didn't likeI miss the Black Mesa setting, and didn't really like how the story just jumped ahead in time. (I'm still hoping for a game that tells more about the events in between HL1 and HL2.)How messianic and famous and revered Gordon is in HL2. I liked it much better in HL1 when you were just some guy trying to survive. It's especially annoying how your resistance fighter allies treat you.I miss the outlandish weapons from HL1 and Opposing Force.Enemies, too. I miss the alien and varied enemies of HL1. In HL2 you're mostly fighting humans.All those loading screens. Gosh, so many loading screens. And you see a long corridor with a bend at the end and you just *know* there's a loading screen coming.That ending sucked. It worked in HL1 because it was the first time. But HL2 also ending with you being "shelved"? Not cool. (All was forgiven with the beginning scene of HL2 episode 1.)I remember playing through this on New Year's eve. Fun times. Oh and, if you're getting this, get Episode 1 and 2 also. HL2 Episode 2 is my favourite of the entire series.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												15 years later and this game is still better than most of the games coming out today.  This is my first time playing through this and it is one of the most brutal and completely rewarding games I have ever played.  The whole game just plays through start to finish.  No cutscenes or out of game sequences.  Everything happens in the game as you play.  There are no arrows, button prompts, lines to follow or help of any kind as how to proceed, I love it.  This game demands that you think about how you will get through every test of your skill.  This is what games need to be like.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Absolutely phenomenal game. After hearing all the hype about the Half-Life series, I had to give it a try. As you'd probably guess, I was very impressed with it. The story of Gordon Freeman is strange yet intriguing. The implication of the Gman in this part of the series was well-placed. Honestly, this IS the best FPS I've ever played. Bottom line; if you haven't played Half-Life, do it. You will enjoy it. I cannot wait for Valve to begin developing Half-Life 3 (or HL2: Episode 3).

content:
Posted: August 29, 2013
												The Orange Box, or perhaps Half Life 2 itself, is the greatest value in all of gaming history. Why? Because with just HL2 you unlock the ability to literally play thousands of free mods, some of which are of higher quality or more fun than HL2 itself, as well as the tools to make your own mods and maps. If you haven't played HL1 and are worried about HL2, Don't. The story is just as bizarre as ever and the token "unexplainable ending" of all Half Life games has returned yet again.

												Игра всех времён и народов! Однозначно, без базара. Идеал игростроения. Совершенство симбиоза геймплея и сюжета. Может казаться, что надо быть поехавшим чтобы игру, рассчитанную на 12-13 часов прохождения, играть вот уже 10 год подряд оставляя за собой море времени, тысячи часов прохождения первой части, различных дополнений официальных и не только, 2-ой части, эпизодов и т.д. - но это единственная игра, которая уводит тебя под саунды Келли Бэйли в мир Half-Life, в мир где "он — словно озарение, после него понимаешь, какой гадостью тебя кормили последние годы". Мир, который как бриллиант, который навсегда. Который при каждом новом запуске оного открывается по разному. Закончу цитатой известного издательства: "Если вы видели Half-Life 2, то считайте, что видели лучшую компьютерную игру на этой планете". О да! О да!! ДА!

content:
Posted: July 5, 2011
												Video Playthrough


YouTube™ Video: Dirty Plays: Half-Life 2:Update (Part 1) 

			Views: 40		

			This is the first time I've done anything like this and I spent a while getting the audio to a suitable level. however if you think it's off or you have any other criticism, let me know.		

This is the follow up to the masterpiece that was the original Half-Life.This game has a beautiful story, amazing graphics, great A.I. which is still rare to see in games even today.You'll have a vast array of weapons that you'll pick up throughout the game, each of them feeling unique with, damage, range, effects and occasionally secondary fire.Driving sequences are fun and smooth to play.The game is full of memorable characters. Both good and evil.Synopsis: You are Gordon Freeman, a scientist that worked at the Black Mesa Research Facility, You've just been awoken from stasis by the G-man, after the 7 hour war between the human resistance and the Combine. You'll meet up with new and old characters alike and try to take the earth back from the Combine.If you still haven't played this game, I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												This is in my top 3 games of all time. For me, everything just clicks in this game, but most notably the atmosphere and characters. First off, you do not need to have played the first half life to appreatate this one, and in fact the first time I played HL2, I barely even knew what the first one was about. The dystopian setting has always been one of my favorites, and this game protrays this perfectly. Everything in the game seems as if it is barely working and is about to fall apart. Although the game is now nearly 10 years old, its graphics still look pleasing, and the art style is as amazing as always. The level variety is stunning, and thoughout the ten hour campagin, it never begins to become boring. The characters feel like people, and you begin to genuinely care about them. Each weapon feels unique, and I ended up using almost all of them at one point or another. (Something I think they improved over Half Life 1) This game is basically created Steam, so please buy this wonderful game! And if this game doesnt sound interesting to you, there are litterally hundreads of mods, so almost as great as the orginal game. There is no reason not to buy this game, though if you have the money, get the Orange Box for sure, as it has much more value. Pros:+Story+Gameplay+Characters+Physics+Litterally everythingNeutral:*No multiplayer (But it doesnt need it)Overall: 10/10 I love this game, and have played though it about four times. I can find nearly no flaws, please buy this game, you have no idea what you are missing.

												Still stands to this day as the best driven action/sci-fi game of all time. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												Like its predecessor, Half-Life 2 is a single-player first-person shooter broken into several chapters, permanently casting the player as the protagonist Gordon Freeman. The sequel has nearly the same mechanics as Half-Life, including health-and-weapon systems and periodic physics puzzles, except with the newer Source Engine and improved graphics. The player also starts without items, slowly building up an arsenal over the course of the game. Despite the game's mainly linear nature, much effort was put into making exploration rewarding and interesting; many optional areas can be missed or avoided.A diverse set of enemies are present, which usually require being approached with different tactics: some coordinate in groups to out-maneuver or out-position the player; others, like the Manhack, fly directly at the player through small openings and tight corridors; some use predictable but powerful attacks, while others hide before swiftly attacking the player. Gordon can kill most enemies with his weapons, or make use of indirect means, exploiting environmental hazards such as explosive pressurized canisters, gas fires or improvised traps. At one point in the game, Gordon can be joined by up to four armed Resistance soldiers, and can send his team further from him or call them back; however, they can still die easily due to lack of damage protection. Squad members are indicated on the HUD (squad member icons with a cross sign are field medics).Many of the game's new features utilize its detailed physics simulation. Two sections of the game involve driving vehicles. Instead of button-based puzzles from Half-Life, environmental puzzles are also introduced with makeshift mechanical systems, revolving around the player's new ability to pick up, move, and place objects. Solutions involve objects' physical properties, such as shape, weight, and buoyancy. For example, in Chapter 3, Route Kanal, the player is required to stack cinder blocks on a makeshift see-saw ramp to proceed over a wall.Part-way through the game, Gordon acquires the Gravity Gun, which allows him to draw distant objects towards himself or forcefully push them away, as well as to manipulate larger and heavier objects than he is able to alone. These abilities are required to solve puzzles later in the game, and can also be used to great effect in combat, as any non-static object within proximity to the player has the potential to be used as a makeshift defense (e.g. a file cabinet) or a deadly projectile (e.g. a gasoline can or a buzzsaw blade).The game never separates the player with pre-rendered cutscenes or events; the story proceeds via exposition from other characters and in-world events, and ensures that the player controls Gordon for the entirety of the game. Much of the backstory to the game is simply alluded to, or told through the environment.Source; http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Half_life_2

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												Half Life is one of the first PC games I owned.  I had it when I plugged a power cable into a lan card and fried it.  Oh young dumb PC accidents.  Half Life 2 is a build upon an already amazing franchise.  One that spawned Counter-Strike and Day of Defeat from free Half Life mods to actual stand alone games that were sold in stores.  Half Life 2 is an incredible game with stunning graphics and great AI - for its time.  The gameplay is fun and with the use of Developer Mode, players that are playing the game through for a second, third, or fourth time can enable fun gravity settings or thousands of other commands.  The story line in the game itself is the classic FPS Hero vs The World.  I would rate this game a 9.2/10 because it is still a classic, a benchmark to gaming, a sequel to one of the best games ever made and still one of the highest META rated games in the world.  Half Life 2 is worth the few dollars to purchase - as well as all of the other Valve titles.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
 "A right man in the wrong place can make all the difference in the world." TL;DR: ...why don't you have this in your Steam liabry if you're a Steam user?Half-Life 2 is the sequel to the smash-hit debut title for Valve. Half-Life had revolutionary graphics engine, amazing A.I, logical puzzles and an engaging story- nothing like other FPS games that came out before Half-Life. Half-Life won over 50 awards, and is to this date announced as the 'best FPS game ever made'. And Half-Life 2 is the direct sequel to this masterpiece, so it has to live up to its expectations, though cliches with sequels are that they are only made to milk money. THAT is not true with Half-LIfe 2.Not only Half-Life 2 also had a ground-breaking physics engine called Source, it leaved the 'closed enviorment' atmosphere behind, but used it to make a even better written storyline.Now, keep in mind that Half-Life 2 was made in 2004. I will be reviewing this game like it came out in 2004, but also as if it came out in modern times.The Source engine is still a pretty good engine now, but back then, it was amazing. The signature weapon of the game, the Gravity Gun, was made specifically to show out this new physics. You can't play the original Source engine from 2004 because they updated all games that used the engine to have the updated version from Half-Life 2: Episode 2, so you mostly won't suffer from the engines cons, but back then, the sound engine was terrible for the Source.The story continues right where you left off. You were hired by the 'G-Man' because he was impressed at your skills, and put you into stasis untill the time came. Now, it's time to smell the ashes, and Gordon Freeman, the physicist you're contolling, has to join up with the Rebels to fight off the alien 'Combine' forces. The Combine are this galactic federation that enslaves every alien species come by, and puts them as the member of their 'union'. The humans had a 7-hour long war with them, until the UN HQ burnt down and Earth surrendered.In Half-Life, the first bit of the game was you trying to get the ♥♥♥♥ out of Black Mesa, the research facility you were working. Then your mission was to save the world from suffering the same misery Black Mesa suffered by killing the invaders' master and ending the invasion. But Gordon was a bit too late, and the invaders found a way out of Black Mesa(which was just teleporting there) before Gordon did. But since Gordon did kill their master, they stopped fighting the humans(except for the non-inteligent ones). Then the Combine came, and this is where you start.As the story goes along, the level change drastically. You start at a big city, goes to a canal, a dead town, a coast, a desert, a prison, then back to the city to finally blow up the Citadel, the Combine's base of operations for Earth. While the gameplay doesn't change a lot thoughout the game, the atmosphere do.Now, the gameplay is nothing special in my book- it's pretty good(or above average depending on your look). You shoot guns to kill people. Though you can use physics against your enemies with your special 'Gravity Gun'. The Gravity Gun allows you to pick up heavy objects and just throw them wherever you wish it to. This can definetely result in some funny moments, and can vary up the gameplay.The playtime for Half-Life is much longer then any other FPS games that came out around 2004(Halo 3, Doom 3, Modern Warfare, etc). The average playtime for those games were about 6~8 hours, while Half-Life's playtime is around 8~10 hours. Nothing special compared to modern games(well, actually maybe it is), but still pretty good for a 2004 game.The puzzles are back from Half-Life, though this time, a lot of the puzzles are about physics(not because the protagonist is a physicist, but to show off the engine). It involves simple tasks such as moving things to point A to point B, to puzzles like throwing barrels so it makes a bridge(a bit similiar puzzle is from Half-Life: Blue Shift).Let's talk about some miscellaneous stuff. The graphics were good at the time, but by today standards, it's average(even below avarage). The soundtrack is more of the same with Half-Life 1 actually, with some remixes and a few new tracks. It still takes advantage of the ambient themes.I probably don't even need to make this review any longer- as you may already have noticed, Half-Life 2 is an amazing game. But many people don't go over the cons for the game, and some of them are blantly obvious.The A.I. Jesus Christ, the A.I. It's not terrible, but considering Half-Life 1 was revolutionary in its A.I. programming, it was very dissapointing. A good game to compare this is Halo: Combat Evolved. In that game, the enemies flanked you, took defensive positions, etc. While Half-Life 1's A.I. was fantastic at the time, if you compare 1998 with 2004, it's not very different. And Half-Life 2 didn't have much better A.I. then its prequel.(the companions A.I. is a bit improved though)The game is really really easy. Really really really. I mean, Half-Life 1 was easy, but this game is just out there. I highly suggest not even touching the 'easy difficulty', A.K.A 'you can't ♥♥♥♥ing die difficulty'. There are also vehicles in the game, and while it's pretty fun, some parts are just fillers. Oh, and the ending is not that good. I also suggest buying the 'Orange Box', which includes Half-Life 2, its episodic sequels(that fills up the dissapointing ending), and a few other really great games.So we come down to the verdict. I give Half-Life 2 a solid(not really) 7.7/10. It's a great game, for reals. If Half-Life 1 was what every FPS should aim to be, Half-Life 2 is a bit more meh. While the Source engine is an amazing engine, Half-Life 2 doesn't do enough to really stand out on its own currently in 2015. But eleven years earlier, it was amazing.Once again, I highly suggest you to buy the Orange Box, and perhaps Half-Life 1 as well(it's a better game overall except for the story and the graphics). Them, Counter-Strike: Source, and Garry's Mod are a must buy if you're a Steam user.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												Oh boy, Half-Life 2. The sequel to one of the greatest single player first-person shooters ever made. Unlike with that game, I wouldn't say that this game hasn't aged well, but rather other games have done what this game did better since this game came out. Although this is an FPS, you aren't just killing things then entire time. Sometimes you have to drive a vehicle and sometimes you have to solve a puzzle. One of the most prominent features of this game is the Gravity Gun. You can use it as a means of simply moving something somewhere else, or use it as a weapon by launching it at your enemies. This game graphically set the standard for what a 7th generation game should look like, and I still think this game is worth playing for the unique experience it offers. Highly recommended for fans of first person shooters.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												I recommend this game with CAUTION. From what I've played this game supports only one playstyle. If you're not running around constantly dodging bullets and getting up in peoples' faces (aliens, whatever), you're DEAD. I appreciate the lack of regenerating health, though. Half-Life 2 features some of the most annoying enemies ever. They have no personality whatsoever (unlike Wheatley from Portal 2 or the enemies in Halo). Game options could have a "very low to ultra" option to save time. There is little variety in the 3 hours I've played.The story is all right. I'm neither utterly bored by it or blown away. Aliens, resistance, the usual.Puzzles are all right. Navigation, though, is another story. In the beginning of the game, there is a canal you have to walk through. The way to continue is on the SIDE of a box, and the game doesn't give a hint where you're supposed to go. Batman gave subtle hints to the player through his inner thoughts in the Arkham games. Gordon Freeman didn't have to speak, but seriously, the exploration system definitely detracted from the experience.Gun variety is HORRIBLE. You have to play with the same gun until you reach a certain point in which you can pick up a new gun. Rinse and repeat. Now, I know the generic alien army Combines are supposed to carry the same weapons, but couldn't the resistance give/modify cool weapons like in any good resistance story?Conclusion: If you are willing to run around like Duke Nukem most of the game guns blazing, then spend your money on this. If you are willing to do puzzles, spend your money on this. If you are willing to wait a couple of levels to get a new gun, spend your money on this. I can barely recommend this game, because the playstyle it forced me to use made me more alert and fast. I can't say that I had a lot of fun, though.

												Half-Life 2 is one of the most deserving works of any vested gamer's attention. content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Half-Life 2 is undoubtedly my favorite game of all time. Valve managed to create lovable and relatable characters, while keeping a strong story at the game's core. I find myself replaying this game constantly. Whether it's to test some glitch out, try my hand at speedrunning, or for nostalgia's sake, every time I launch the game for a playthrough, it feels just as good as my first time ever launching it. This game, without a doubt, will stand the test of time for years to come. In the unlikely event that you've never heard of or seen gameplay of Half-Life 2, this game is a must-play for any story-driven gaming enthusiast.

Posted: June 24, 2014
Word of advice: Download the demo first and check how you FEEL.I recently started playing Half-Life 2 and even though it's a great game, with nice graphics, interesting story and speech it makes me so NAUSEOUS, LIGHT-HEADED and WEAK (like 15 to 20 minutes after I started playing). I did some research about it and it turns out it's quite common with some HL players, for this reason I urge you to try it before buying it!I have tried the game on 3 different occasions and I always get the same results, I will try and change the settings to see if I can fix this issue or make it so that I won't feel as bad as I do now. If everything fails, I will probably stop playing it, which is a shame. Regardless of playing only 2.8hrs over 2 days I can say that this game has a very well written narrative, the gameplay is quite nice as well, considering the age of this game. I know that for some people the art work could be better but I don't mind it at all. I rather have an interesting game with poor art work than the opposite.

 You are living half a life if you haven't played this yet. - Not Actually Madlabba Welcome to Half-Life 2, truly a masterpiece. This game was really ahead of it's time, setting an example for future videogame titles, like Duke Nukem Forever, or Limbo of the Lost.The story revolves around the protagonist - a survivor of the Black Mesa incident from the first game. This time he is in some post-soviet country, rallying up a rebellion to stop the alien rule over human race. He is quite charismatic it seems, because everyone is ready to die in order to keep him alive. And his name was.. ELI VANCE That's right. Your favourite videogame character is back to kick some♥♥♥♥♥ Or be taken hostage for half of the game. Either work for him, because he is so badass.

												Now, before I get started, I just want to get one thing straight: This is not at all a bad game! That being said, I don't see what all of the hype is about. First of all, if you have no idea what this game is, don't worry, nobody who's played this game does either. Half Life 2 is incredibly confusing, albeit only storywise: the actual gameplay mechanics are fairly simple. My main problem with this game is that at some points, it just gets repetitive. However, most of the time it's fairly amusing and I thoroughly enjoyed it. All in all, a solid 7 / 10.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Half-Life 2 is a brilliant combination of good story telling and extrodinary gameplay. Easily one of the best games I have ever played. Delivered with an emotional and immersive story, with some of the most memorable characters I've ever encountered in a video game. The gameplay is a nod to getting rid of all of the fancy, confusing gunplay of most modern shooters. Leaving it with a simple but, in no doubt memorable adventure through the ever so immersing world. I had no complaints at all when I was playing, and enjoyed every moment I spent in this game. Easily one of if not the best first person shooter to this date. I am still patiently waiting for the sequel (If it's ever even released) and reccomend everyone play this game, espessially if you are new to PC gaming, this is a great place to start.10/10Best game of all time

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Superb game, part of my favorite overall series.Pros:*Characters are consisted in an array of quirkiness, relatability, good AI, and helpfulness (albeit frustrating in the occasional tight rooms).*Great for fans of science fiction (teleportation, aliens that aren't just humans with green skin) as well as liking the occasional science reference thrown in.*World is bleak, but not crushingly so, and full of dystopian fantasies that are implemented without too much hammering in. *Gameplay is without traditional cutscenes, very few mobility obstacles, fast at a reasonable pace, and is broken off by story scenes to prevent action fatigue.*Soundtrack presents a nice blend of futuristic techno with eerie ambience.*Not every alien is a jerk. NPCs are likewise generally good and not macho/overly cynical.*The settings range from urban areas, to mines, to abandoned towns, to coastlines, and radioactive wastelands.*Great facial animations.Cons:*The protagonist never speaks, which can put off some.*While there is some exploration, it is mostly a very linear game.*Driving sections usually are longer than they have to be.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												The greatest FPS fps of all time. It may not be some heavily gameplay design focused super polished masterpiece like Doom. However the atmosphere, the characters, the physics and environment interaction that still hold up, every big to subtle tid bit of detail where you can tell they poured every ounce of talent and soul into, it all just comes together to make one of the most profound video games ever made. Not to say the gameplay isn't special, for being the game series that sort of set off the whole trend of a more linear focused level design punctuated by amazing scripted events, the gameplay is still miles ahead of most modern FPS games today that do the same thing. One of the things that captures me the most about this game is the absolute sheer amount of variation of different situations this game throws at you. The game absolutely never gets repetitive at all, the game always tosses situations at you that you never really have done beforehand in the game. The fact that the game still captures that feeling of immersion without ever having to sacrifice that feeling in order to make the level design gameplay oriented is just amazing.I could go on but I don't really think too many people would read this, and everyone already knows how good this game is. All I can say is that it gives off that feeling of wonder and detail, of a full emotional yet functional and fun experience, like no other game before or after yet.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												There are a lot of video games out there. From shooters, to racers, to RPG's to RTS's... It has never been a better time to be a gamer nowadays. The choice we have as gamers is overwhelming, and even though there are a lot of flawed products out there, a lot of great titles make their way into our libraries on an yearly basis. As I see it, video games are divided into three categories: Bad, Decent, and Great, from worse to best. But some games are so unique, different and so many light years ahead of everything else, they don't quite fall under any kind of category. I know a few of these games myself. Half Life 2 is also light years ahead of those games.Half Life 2 is an experience. It's almost movie like in it's immersion. I found myself caring about the protagonist, Gordon Freeman, my allies Alyx and Eli Vance, Dr Mossman and Dr K, in the fight against the fascist alien race known as the combine. I found myself caring about every little detail of what happened to them, and to my surprise, I have never felt this happy, sad and angry while playing a video game. It truly is an experience.I won't spoil the story to anyone, but it is by far, and in my opinion, the best story ever put into the video game form, for what it tells you, for what you have to figure out for yourself, and for the most intriguing and misterious character to ever grace a PC game (or any game for that matter): The G-man. When you play this game, you will know exactly what I am talking about. Gameplay is varied, and the controls are close to perfection. You will walk and shoot like an FPS, drive a boat and buggy. The common link between them is the fact they are seamless and feel like you are on a true quest, no section is out of place and they are all extremely well done. The concept of levels isn't quite present, as the game world feels like a whole.Half life 2 is an amazing accomplishment. It is the proof that games can be art, and can rival Hollywood in story telling. Make no mistake, Half Life 2 is in my opinion, the best game ever made, and worth every penny and minute you put into it. It is a rewarding experience like no other, and there are almost no games who can even compare to it. A timeless masterpiece.The GoodExtremely fun to playGroundbreaking storyEnemy AIShooting mechanicsVaried gameplay The BadNothing I can think of, it really is that good, and as close to perfection as you will ever get.10/10 - Legendary

content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												Oh, good old Half-Life series. While gamers are still waiting for Half-Life 3, they can just complete the second part over and over again, and every time they do that, they'll discover something new. Half-Life 2 is a game full of secrets, surprises, and great level design features. I wouldn't say it's better than Half-Life 1 but that's only because they are so different that they can't actually be compared.So, what does this game have to offer? For me, it is the following:1. A great storyline.Not that Half-Life 1, the origin of the series, had a worse one, no. But now Half-Life 2 has a lot more dialogues than the first game, and they are a lot more detailed. The story is no longer a "human vs. alien" cliché, Valve turned it into a very original, very clever "human AND aliens vs. mutated humans controlled by a man controlled by a mysterious thing previously controlled by Nihilanth". Sounds good.2. Great graphics.I have no desire to know what Call of Duty fans would say about the graphics in Half-Life 2. For me, they will always stay as awesome as I thought when I first saw them. Seriously, look at this game. It came from 2004 (11 years ago). Now, check other games from 2004 and look at them. Half-Life 2 is the obvious winner. In 2015, it still looks pretty. At least, for me.3. Physics.Physics! Boxes breaking into really small parts! Carry boxes with yourself! What else could you dream of in 2004? In Half-Life 2, physics are just awesome, without exaggeration.4. Alyx.A woman companion. I wouldn't say she looks as nice yet having a woman accompanying you is a great feature. Especially if she can shoot at enemies and even kill them sometimes. What else do you need?5. Puzzles.The campaign of Half-Life 2 is not linear. That's what makes it beautiful: lots of puzzling elements (I keep getting stuck at some levels if I don't play this game, say, for a month or two). Totally not like Call of Duty, the best shooting range game of all times. In this game, you don't simply go from point A to point B, you discover secrets, solve puzzles, escape from a hunter chopper, and only meanwhile, fight enemies.These are only 5 features I'd most like to point out. There are always much more but to discover them, you have to play the game yourself. I totally recommend this game, it deserves ten stars out of five but I can't rate it this way, unfortunately. But keep in mind that you still have to play Half-Life 1 to get into the story.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												This is in my top 3 games of all time. For me, everything just clicks in this game, but most notably the atmosphere and characters. First off, you do not need to have played the first half life to appreatate this one, and in fact the first time I played HL2, I barely even knew what the first one was about. The dystopian setting has always been one of my favorites, and this game protrays this perfectly. Everything in the game seems as if it is barely working and is about to fall apart. Although the game is now nearly 10 years old, its graphics still look pleasing, and the art style is as amazing as always. The level variety is stunning, and thoughout the ten hour campagin, it never begins to become boring. The characters feel like people, and you begin to genuinely care about them. Each weapon feels unique, and I ended up using almost all of them at one point or another. (Something I think they improved over Half Life 1) This game is basically created Steam, so please buy this wonderful game! And if this game doesnt sound interesting to you, there are litterally hundreads of mods, so almost as great as the orginal game. There is no reason not to buy this game, though if you have the money, get the Orange Box for sure, as it has much more value. Pros:+Story+Gameplay+Characters+Physics+Litterally everythingNeutral:*No multiplayer (But it doesnt need it)Overall: 10/10 I love this game, and have played though it about four times. I can find nearly no flaws, please buy this game, you have no idea what you are missing.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												In some ways, this is a very old-fashioned FPS.  You have a variety of weapons, but can only hold so much ammo.   When you pick up stuff (by touching it), it adds those bullets/health to your supplies if you have any missing, and any excess is lost.  Carrying around health packs/extra ammo is impossible.  You still progress through a bunch of areas, needing to press the right button or trigger the right event to proceed.What sets it apart is the obvious polish, quality design, and good story.  The game uses only in-engine cinematics, and never takes over the player's camera.  It counts on you to observe the world around you, take an interest in the environment, and solve the various physics puzzles.  Instead of just a bunch of corridors and enemies (though it has those, too), it focuses on small engagements, then big set-piece battles.  You'll play for a while in one setting on foot, then switch to a more vehicle-oriented bit, then a new mechanic is introduced, then it kind of repeats those 3, etc.  This varies up the gameplay and keeps introducing fresh concepts through little in-game tutorials.About the only complaint I had is that the game wants you to be immersed in its world, and use their impressive physics engine to solve puzzles.  It wants you to approach the obstacles as if you were actually there, making use of the objects around you to get past them.  This is great when it works, like making use of plastic barrels' buoyancy to get past one spot, but then you get to points where you try out a solution over and over, convinced it should be working, and it won't.  Oh, it should work, because it seems obvious, and because it totally would work in the real world, but in the game they want you to do something else pre-scripted, and until you figure out what that thing is, you're not going anywhere.  They make you stack boxes & crates in several spots to climb up/over things, but try it in the wrong place and you'll hit an invisible wall.  There's one area where you have to get past an electric fence and can see the power cable running above you.  Even though you've got a way to hurl nice big, sharp, wide saw blades with great speed and accuracy, you can't sever that cable.  No amount of shooting will help, either.  That cable's not a solid object, it's just there to let you know where to go to hit the switch that you need to find in order to turn off the fence.Despite a few tired elements and some minor breaks in the immersion, this is one hell of a game.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												One of the greatest story driven FPS ever made. You don't need to play the first game to appreciate this one, but there are a lot of references to the first game that you will only understand if you played it. Every detail of this game is very highly polished. All the characters act in a way that is very realistic and you can tell a lot of work went into making them. There are a few unique weapons to this game. The Gravity Gun, Antlion summoning ball, and the crossbow with a scope that can attach enemies to walls were all amazing weapons. The town of Ravenholm looks like it was made for all the zombie lovers out there. After all this time, the game still doesn't look dated that much. Most of the graphics looks pretty decent and the mechanics are still solid. The game will last around 12 hours, depending on how much you explore.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												10/10This game is definitely one of the best on Steam. I've had so much fun playing through it. The world is well developed, immersive, and interactable. You can shoot sawblades into wooden objects to keep them there while you perform another task. You can shoot paint cans at objects, and it will turn them white. You can crouch behind a crashed car and push it up towards baddies until you run them over. You can get in a crane and drop shipping containers on people. Most of the challenge comes from just finding your way around. Despite the fact that a simple scientist is capable of killing so many people, the story is unique and captivating. The gameplay is diverse, challenging, and fun. The environment is lovely, which is typical of all the production aspects of this game. In my opinion every gamer should experience this game.10/10 would get jumpscared by an antlion again.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Half-Life 2 is widely known as one of the greatest games of all time, and for good reason. Almost everything about this game is perfect. The pacing is great, and it keeps you on the edge of your seat from the moment you step out of the train in City 17 right up until the epic conclusion. The guns are punchy, not to mention the Gravity Gun's awesome power. The story is immersive and fantastic, and the entire game feels like a journey, partly due to the fact that there is never a cutscene that you have to sit through. Valve's Source Engine has put so much life into this game, especially the characters. The facial animations are believeable, to the point where I would feel empathy for the characters, the physics are good (Yet sometimes laughable) and the gameplay is fantastic. You are immersed in a living, breathing world right from the get-go. Half-Life 2 is an incredible game that demands to be played by everyone who has any interest in  the shooter genre  video games at all.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
-Quick Review-Half-Life 2 is a First Person Shooter developed by Valve and released late 2004. This is actually the first game I owned and played on my steam account, I cannot speak highly enough of the whole Half-Life series.-Detailed breakdown review-Story: Half-Life 2 starts on a train arriving at City 17, you play as the protagonist “Gordon Freeman”, get used to that name, because everyone knows it and exclaims it when they see you. (Well, everyone but the “Combine” police force, when they first see you in the introduction level at City 17.)Not long after getting off the train, you come across old acquaintances Dr. Kleiner and Barney Calhoun, they send Gordon on his way to join up with an underground group known as the "Lambda Resistance".I won't risk saying and spoiling anything about the rest of story; this is one of the games that I contrast against many other story telling narratives – because it's so well done. Even replaying the game after so many years, Half-Life 2 is still a very enjoyable game and I believe the series will survive the test of time to become a staple in video game history. (At LEAST Steam history)


Uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Half-Life 2
By: Atratzu




Gameplay: As you progress through the game you unlock new weapons, and explore new area's, you can switch between your weapons with the scroll wheel or number keys, sometimes you double up on the same weapon categories (for example, you might have two pistols, or two rifles so you'll need to scroll through both of those, or hit the key twice to rotate between them)All of your standard FPS's are in the game, your basic “go to” (Bread-and-butter, Rice-and-beans, defaulted-to, basic, etc) weapons are: The crowbar, pistol, and Submachine Gun.The weapons you unlock are: Crowbar, Gravity Gun, Bugbait, 9mm pistol, .357 Magnum, SMG, AR2 Pulse Rifle, Shotgun, Crossbow, Grenade, and RPG.


Uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Half-Life 2
By: Atratzu




Achievements: About half of the achievements in Half-Life 2 are unlocked on your first play through, the other half are Easter eggs, or various objectives challanges.The hardest/longest achievement is Lambda Locator, which requires you to find each Lambda Cache. (The Greek letter “L” is known as Lambda “λ”) As you play through the game you will sometimes come across a “λ” Lambda, that means there's a Lambda Resistance weapons cache nearby.


We don't go to Ravenholm... 
A Screenshot of Half-Life 2
By: Atratzu




Price: The standalone price for Half-Life 2 is $9.99 you will probably come close to nine hours of gameplay within this game. I've personally replayed the story several times so for me it was a great value.However, I have a better recommendation; if you are thinking about getting Half-Life 2, Half-Life 2: Episode One, Half-Life 2: Episode Two, and/or Portal, you should purchase The Orange Box for $19.99, you will get all of the afore mentioned game titles.Conclusion: Story: Excellent, a personal all-time favorite of mine. Gameplay: Solid controls, solid physics, solid, solid solid. Even after all these years the game is still very good. Achievements: Fairly doable 100% completed game. Price: Fair, but I suggest getting the Orange Box deal.I recommend this game to people who enjoy darker serious stories, FPS's, or don't swear by the latest game releases (Translation: you as a gamer are backwards compatible with older games/graphics/engines).Thanks for reading my review! I have a couple great stories of my first experience in Ravenholm when I was younger, if you'd like to hear them drop me a message.Related reviewsHere's the URL to see my review for  Half-Life 2: Episode OneHere's the URL to see my review for  Half-Life 2: Episode TwoHere's the URL to see my review for Half-Life 3 ...(All you hear is muffled crying)

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Superb game, part of my favorite overall series.Pros:*Characters are consisted in an array of quirkiness, relatability, good AI, and helpfulness (albeit frustrating in the occasional tight rooms).*Great for fans of science fiction (teleportation, aliens that aren't just humans with green skin) as well as liking the occasional science reference thrown in.*World is bleak, but not crushingly so, and full of dystopian fantasies that are implemented without too much hammering in. *Gameplay is without traditional cutscenes, very few mobility obstacles, fast at a reasonable pace, and is broken off by story scenes to prevent action fatigue.*Soundtrack presents a nice blend of futuristic techno with eerie ambience.*Not every alien is a jerk. NPCs are likewise generally good and not macho/overly cynical.*The settings range from urban areas, to mines, to abandoned towns, to coastlines, and radioactive wastelands.*Great facial animations.Cons:*The protagonist never speaks, which can put off some.*While there is some exploration, it is mostly a very linear game.*Driving sections usually are longer than they have to be.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												The greatest FPS fps of all time. It may not be some heavily gameplay design focused super polished masterpiece like Doom. However the atmosphere, the characters, the physics and environment interaction that still hold up, every big to subtle tid bit of detail where you can tell they poured every ounce of talent and soul into, it all just comes together to make one of the most profound video games ever made. Not to say the gameplay isn't special, for being the game series that sort of set off the whole trend of a more linear focused level design punctuated by amazing scripted events, the gameplay is still miles ahead of most modern FPS games today that do the same thing. One of the things that captures me the most about this game is the absolute sheer amount of variation of different situations this game throws at you. The game absolutely never gets repetitive at all, the game always tosses situations at you that you never really have done beforehand in the game. The fact that the game still captures that feeling of immersion without ever having to sacrifice that feeling in order to make the level design gameplay oriented is just amazing.I could go on but I don't really think too many people would read this, and everyone already knows how good this game is. All I can say is that it gives off that feeling of wonder and detail, of a full emotional yet functional and fun experience, like no other game before or after yet.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Half-Life 2 is a brilliant combination of good story telling and extrodinary gameplay. Easily one of the best games I have ever played. Delivered with an emotional and immersive story, with some of the most memorable characters I've ever encountered in a video game. The gameplay is a nod to getting rid of all of the fancy, confusing gunplay of most modern shooters. Leaving it with a simple but, in no doubt memorable adventure through the ever so immersing world. I had no complaints at all when I was playing, and enjoyed every moment I spent in this game. Easily one of if not the best first person shooter to this date. I am still patiently waiting for the sequel (If it's ever even released) and reccomend everyone play this game, espessially if you are new to PC gaming, this is a great place to start.10/10Best game of all time

content:
Posted: June 8, 2012
												The game changer. The bar to which all other FPS's should judge themselves and be judged by.Upon it's release Half Life 2 was cutting edge, not just for a follow up FPS, but for games in general.Graphics and set peices that hold up even now, 8 years on from it's release.Gravity effects, AI that flanks, nades, covers and changes their behavior seeds with every load and save made.Topped off with totally immersive story and charcters, a must for any dystopian/ Orwellian fan. After opening a portal to another world at the Black Mesa research facility in Half Life, the Earth came to the attention of an all powerful Alien force, who after brushing aside all of the worlds defences in the '7 hour war' have now enslaved humanity and are slowy draining the planet of all its' natural resorces.Order is maintainted via a 'combine' military force of half alien half human hybrids that have grouped up the remaining human kind into large rundown numbered Citys."Wake up and smell the ashes"

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
 "A right man in the wrong place can make all the difference in the world." TL;DR: ...why don't you have this in your Steam liabry if you're a Steam user?Half-Life 2 is the sequel to the smash-hit debut title for Valve. Half-Life had revolutionary graphics engine, amazing A.I, logical puzzles and an engaging story- nothing like other FPS games that came out before Half-Life. Half-Life won over 50 awards, and is to this date announced as the 'best FPS game ever made'. And Half-Life 2 is the direct sequel to this masterpiece, so it has to live up to its expectations, though cliches with sequels are that they are only made to milk money. THAT is not true with Half-LIfe 2.Not only Half-Life 2 also had a ground-breaking physics engine called Source, it leaved the 'closed enviorment' atmosphere behind, but used it to make a even better written storyline.Now, keep in mind that Half-Life 2 was made in 2004. I will be reviewing this game like it came out in 2004, but also as if it came out in modern times.The Source engine is still a pretty good engine now, but back then, it was amazing. The signature weapon of the game, the Gravity Gun, was made specifically to show out this new physics. You can't play the original Source engine from 2004 because they updated all games that used the engine to have the updated version from Half-Life 2: Episode 2, so you mostly won't suffer from the engines cons, but back then, the sound engine was terrible for the Source.The story continues right where you left off. You were hired by the 'G-Man' because he was impressed at your skills, and put you into stasis untill the time came. Now, it's time to smell the ashes, and Gordon Freeman, the physicist you're contolling, has to join up with the Rebels to fight off the alien 'Combine' forces. The Combine are this galactic federation that enslaves every alien species come by, and puts them as the member of their 'union'. The humans had a 7-hour long war with them, until the UN HQ burnt down and Earth surrendered.In Half-Life, the first bit of the game was you trying to get the ♥♥♥♥ out of Black Mesa, the research facility you were working. Then your mission was to save the world from suffering the same misery Black Mesa suffered by killing the invaders' master and ending the invasion. But Gordon was a bit too late, and the invaders found a way out of Black Mesa(which was just teleporting there) before Gordon did. But since Gordon did kill their master, they stopped fighting the humans(except for the non-inteligent ones). Then the Combine came, and this is where you start.As the story goes along, the level change drastically. You start at a big city, goes to a canal, a dead town, a coast, a desert, a prison, then back to the city to finally blow up the Citadel, the Combine's base of operations for Earth. While the gameplay doesn't change a lot thoughout the game, the atmosphere do.Now, the gameplay is nothing special in my book- it's pretty good(or above average depending on your look). You shoot guns to kill people. Though you can use physics against your enemies with your special 'Gravity Gun'. The Gravity Gun allows you to pick up heavy objects and just throw them wherever you wish it to. This can definetely result in some funny moments, and can vary up the gameplay.The playtime for Half-Life is much longer then any other FPS games that came out around 2004(Halo 3, Doom 3, Modern Warfare, etc). The average playtime for those games were about 6~8 hours, while Half-Life's playtime is around 8~10 hours. Nothing special compared to modern games(well, actually maybe it is), but still pretty good for a 2004 game.The puzzles are back from Half-Life, though this time, a lot of the puzzles are about physics(not because the protagonist is a physicist, but to show off the engine). It involves simple tasks such as moving things to point A to point B, to puzzles like throwing barrels so it makes a bridge(a bit similiar puzzle is from Half-Life: Blue Shift).Let's talk about some miscellaneous stuff. The graphics were good at the time, but by today standards, it's average(even below avarage). The soundtrack is more of the same with Half-Life 1 actually, with some remixes and a few new tracks. It still takes advantage of the ambient themes.I probably don't even need to make this review any longer- as you may already have noticed, Half-Life 2 is an amazing game. But many people don't go over the cons for the game, and some of them are blantly obvious.The A.I. Jesus Christ, the A.I. It's not terrible, but considering Half-Life 1 was revolutionary in its A.I. programming, it was very dissapointing. A good game to compare this is Halo: Combat Evolved. In that game, the enemies flanked you, took defensive positions, etc. While Half-Life 1's A.I. was fantastic at the time, if you compare 1998 with 2004, it's not very different. And Half-Life 2 didn't have much better A.I. then its prequel.(the companions A.I. is a bit improved though)The game is really really easy. Really really really. I mean, Half-Life 1 was easy, but this game is just out there. I highly suggest not even touching the 'easy difficulty', A.K.A 'you can't ♥♥♥♥ing die difficulty'. There are also vehicles in the game, and while it's pretty fun, some parts are just fillers. Oh, and the ending is not that good. I also suggest buying the 'Orange Box', which includes Half-Life 2, its episodic sequels(that fills up the dissapointing ending), and a few other really great games.So we come down to the verdict. I give Half-Life 2 a solid(not really) 7.7/10. It's a great game, for reals. If Half-Life 1 was what every FPS should aim to be, Half-Life 2 is a bit more meh. While the Source engine is an amazing engine, Half-Life 2 doesn't do enough to really stand out on its own currently in 2015. But eleven years earlier, it was amazing.Once again, I highly suggest you to buy the Orange Box, and perhaps Half-Life 1 as well(it's a better game overall except for the story and the graphics). Them, Counter-Strike: Source, and Garry's Mod are a must buy if you're a Steam user.
