You were hired by the 'G-Man' because he was impressed at your skills, and put you into stasis untill the time came. Now, it's time to smell the ashes, and Gordon Freeman, the physicist you're contolling, has to join up with the Rebels to fight off the alien 'Combine' forces. The Combine are this galactic federation that enslaves every alien species come by, and puts them as the member of their 'union'. The humans had a 7-hour long war with them, until the UN HQ burnt down and Earth surrendered.In Half-Life, the first bit of the game was you trying to get the ♥♥♥♥ out of Black Mesa, the research facility you were working. Then your mission was to save the world from suffering the same misery Black Mesa suffered by killing the invaders' master and ending the invasion. But Gordon was a bit too late, and the invaders found a way out of Black Mesa(which was just teleporting there) before Gordon did. But since Gordon did kill their master, they stopped fighting the humans(except for the non-inteligent ones). Then the Combine came, and this is where you start.As the story goes along, the level change drastically. You start at a big city, goes to a canal, a dead town, a coast, a desert, a prison, then back to the city to finally blow up the Citadel, the Combine's base of operations for Earth. While the gameplay doesn't change a lot thoughout the game, the atmosphere do.Now, the gameplay is nothing special in my book- it's pretty good(or above average depending on your look). You shoot guns to kill people. Though you can use physics against your enemies with your special 'Gravity Gun'. The Gravity Gun allows you to pick up heavy objects and just throw them wherever you wish it to. This can definetely result in some funny moments, and can vary up the gameplay.The playtime for Half-Life is much longer then any other FPS games that came out around 2004(Halo 3, Doom 3, Modern Warfare, etc). The average playtime for those games were about 6~8 hours, while Half-Life's playtime is around 8~10 hours. Nothing special compared to modern games(well, actually maybe it is), but still pretty good for a 2004 game.The puzzles are back from Half-Life, though this time, a lot of the puzzles are about physics(not because the protagonist is a physicist, but to show off the engine). It involves simple tasks such as moving things to point A to point B, to puzzles like throwing barrels so it makes a bridge(a bit similiar puzzle is from Half-Life: Blue Shift).Let's talk about some miscellaneous stuff. The graphics were good at the time, but by today standards, it's average(even below avarage). The soundtrack is more of the same with Half-Life 1 actually, with some remixes and a few new tracks. It still takes advantage of the ambient themes.I probably don't even need to make this review any longer- as you may already have noticed, Half-Life 2 is an amazing game. But many people don't go over the cons for the game, and some of them are blantly obvious.The A.I. Jesus Christ, the A.I. It's not terrible, but considering Half-Life 1 was revolutionary in its A.I. programming, it was very dissapointing. A good game to compare this is Halo: Combat Evolved. In that game, the enemies flanked you, took defensive positions, etc. While Half-Life 1's A.I. was fantastic at the time, if you compare 1998 with 2004, it's not very different. And Half-Life 2 didn't have much better A.I. then its prequel.(the companions A.I. is a bit improved though)The game is really really easy. Really really really. I mean, Half-Life 1 was easy, but this game is just out there. I highly suggest not even touching the 'easy difficulty', A.K.A 'you can't ♥♥♥♥ing die difficulty'. There are also vehicles in the game, and while it's pretty fun, some parts are just fillers. Oh, and the ending is not that good. I also suggest buying the 'Orange Box', which includes Half-Life 2, its episodic sequels(that fills up the dissapointing ending), and a few other really great games.So we come down to the verdict. I give Half-Life 2 a solid(not really) 7.7/10. It's a great game, for reals. If Half-Life 1 was what every FPS should aim to be, Half-Life 2 is a bit more meh. While the Source engine is an amazing engine, Half-Life 2 doesn't do enough to really stand out on its own currently in 2015. But eleven years earlier, it was amazing.Once again, I highly suggest you to buy the Orange Box, and perhaps Half-Life 1 as well(it's a better game overall except for the story and the graphics). Them, Counter-Strike: Source, and Garry's Mod are a must buy if you're a Steam user.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												Oh boy, Half-Life 2. The sequel to one of the greatest single player first-person shooters ever made. Unlike with that game, I wouldn't say that this game hasn't aged well, but rather other games have done what this game did better since this game came out. Although this is an FPS, you aren't just killing things then entire time. Sometimes you have to drive a vehicle and sometimes you have to solve a puzzle. One of the most prominent features of this game is the Gravity Gun. You can use it as a means of simply moving something somewhere else, or use it as a weapon by launching it at your enemies. This game graphically set the standard for what a 7th generation game should look like, and I still think this game is worth playing for the unique experience it offers. Highly recommended for fans of first person shooters.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												To start off this review, BUY THIS GAME NOW! I don't care if you have no money just get a job and buy this game. I honestly recommend this as one of the best FPS's out there and possibly one of the all time greatest games ever. This game was pretty ahead of it's time (it came out in 2004) with it's superior graphics and physics engine that contribute to some of the puzzles in the game.The game features a variety of weapons like the Gravity Gun (ftw) and Crossbow (also ftw) and Enemies like the Combine and the Headcrab Zombies (a definite pain in Ravenholme). The game introduces new story ideas and makes use of classic ones. I won't spoil the plot too much but the basic idea is an interdiemensional alien empire known as the combine have taken over Earth and forced the planet into a totalitarien state. You play as Gordon Freeman, a scientist who used to work at Black Mesa and must foil the combines plans to destroy/further takeover the Earth. I recommend that you have at least read a plot synopsis of the original Half-Life before going into Half-Life 2. To summarise, Half-Life 2 is the best Valve game out there and I recommend that you buy this game through The Orange Box to get HL2 episode 1 and 2. Now for Valve to hurry up with HL3.....

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												10/10This game is definitely one of the best on Steam. I've had so much fun playing through it. The world is well developed, immersive, and interactable. You can shoot sawblades into wooden objects to keep them there while you perform another task. You can shoot paint cans at objects, and it will turn them white. You can crouch behind a crashed car and push it up towards baddies until you run them over. You can get in a crane and drop shipping containers on people. Most of the challenge comes from just finding your way around. Despite the fact that a simple scientist is capable of killing so many people, the story is unique and captivating. The gameplay is diverse, challenging, and fun. The environment is lovely, which is typical of all the production aspects of this game. In my opinion every gamer should experience this game.10/10 would get jumpscared by an antlion again.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												I finally began to play Half-life 2 after it sat in my steam library for around 2 years. I finally decided to start playing because I was intrigued. I wanted to see what made this game so highly acclaimed. So much of my game time was spent trying to find the answer to a single question: "Why is Half-life 2 so great?" For a majority of the game I struggled to find the answer. It wasn't that I didn't like the game, it was just I couldn't understand why it was considered to be so amazing. I considered the possibility that the game may have had a different charm back in 2004 when it was released, but the more I played, the more I realized there was much more to the greatness of this game. Onward I struggled with this question and continued to ask myself about what elements made this game so heralded.Was it because of the beloved source engine?Was it because of the quirky and stereotypical FPS story?Was it because of the amazing powers of the gravity gun?Was it because of how well the graphics held up to this day?Was it because of the unique characters?Was it because of the excellent shooting mechanics?Or was it because of the absence of any cutscenes in the game?No, all of these things were good, but they weren't the elements that made Half-life 2 great.The more I searched, the more I realized I was overlooking the one single determining factor in the ability of a game to please its audience. Enjoyment. So I asked myself the question: "Is Half-life 2 fun?" In asking this I realized that what Half-life 2 does so well is the fundamental goal of all games.This is to provide its audience with enjoyment. Half-life 2 does this as well as any game I've ever played. Throughout the game there was never a dull moment. And while all of the elements of this game I mentioned before are great, the game truly excells at making sure you have a good time.

Posted: December 24, 2014
												Let me try to tell you exactly what you're in for, should you decide to purchase Half-Life 2 and attempt to play through it fully.From the very first moment, you will find yourself in a hostile world, where a sense of urgency never leaves you, never lets go; where you can feel the gaze of some almighty force at all times, watching you, regarding you, pursuing you; where you feel almost totally alone, like everything is a hazard, and every force you face is insurmountable.Yet you are Gordon Freeman, theoretical physicist, and that hostile world will be overcome; the gaze of that almighty force will be outrun, averted; and that lonesome road, strewn with hazards, all insurmountable, will be surmounted.You're the right man in the wrong place—and that can make all the difference in the world.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												Half-Life 2 lives up to its name by providing an endearing story with likable characters and an overlooming threat that our favourite silent hero from the first HL game, Gordon Freeman, must rise up and defeat. It remains entertaining even all the way through to Episode 1 and 2, contains unique weapons, great graphics that stand out even today, and an excellent game engine that is still being used by Valve and indie game devs in this day and age. While there are some weapons that just don't feel right in this game whether it's how they feel when firing them or simply holding them and the game has a bad habit of repeating itself in certain instances, I felt HL2 is an excellent game that got's flaws, but that can forgiven for what it delivers in its 15-hour journey.

												Half Life 2 - One of the most anticipated sequels of all time.How exactly do you follow up one of the greatest first person shooters of all time? By making an even better first person shooter! With it's fully upgraded graphics, and an entire new engine, Half Life 2 makes the wait worth it. Dive into a world controlled by an organisation lead by a power hungry overseer. You are Gordon Freeman, the silent hero. Take Gordon from a simple train journey, into a war that will take place on beachheads, on cliff faces, even in abondoned mining towns, and along the way fight humans and aliens alike.You will be instantly hooked on this game, with a storyline that does not disappoint to accompany breathtaking graphics and music.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Half-Life is one of Valve's main franchises, the first game was a huge success, and its long awaited sequel, Half-Life 2, did not disappoint. At its core it's just like your everyday FPS, you go through places, kill some dudes, same old action. However, it's a special game. But why, you ask?When you talk about this game to people who've never played it, they often wonder why does everyone hail it as an amazing masterpiece. Here's the thing. You can't grasp the reason why Half-Life 2 is what it is. I mean, you could try, but it's really one of those games you simply need to experience.Everyone who wants to know how a good FPS is made should play this game. First, its story. It has a surprisingly deep plot that doesn't quite fully show itself to you straight away, and requires attention to detail to understand, though playing the first game will obviously help in this regard.The plot doesn't get too convoluted to the point of not making sense, or too simple to not make you care. That's not to say there won't be moments where you will be wondering what is even going on, but they don't happen out of thin air, and have an explanation, or will have in the future I'm certain, once Valve gets around to continuing the franchise.Yes, it's true, Gordon Freeman doesn't talk, but when you think about it, he doesn't need to. The game does an outstanding job in showing you everything that's happening without Freeman needing to utter a word. He doesn't need to have a preset personality that may conflict with yours and ultimately diminish your enjoyment of the game. What you do, he does. Who you are, he is.Just like the first game, it heavily uses its visuals to tell the story, rather than a static wall of text. This only helps keep it its excellent fluid pacing, feeding you pieces of information as you go along, but not keeping you too much in one place before the action resumes. Having been the first game released with the Source engine, along with Troika's amazing RPG Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines, this game looked great, and still does to this day.But just like I already mentioned in this review, only by playing through Half-Life 2 can you see why it's gathered the amazing fanbase it has, and why it's such a great singleplayer experience. What are you waiting for!? It's super cheap. Go get it and play it now! And Episode 1 and 2 right after, because I bet after completing HL2 you'll want to go through those as well. And then you may join the legion of gamers anxiously waiting for Episode 3.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												Ok so lets say you find a resturaunt that makes a dish so unbelieveably devine that it escapes description. So you go there for the first time with a friend and find out the hype is all true, you wish you could live there it's so good. A week later you go back with a date to find out that they not only upgraded the tables and chairs of the resturaunt they also upgraded the menu as well. After dinner you and your date talk about your amazing experience for weeks and suggest all your friends and family eat there.A week later when you go back again they say that things have changed. Instead of being a sit down and order your meal resturaunt they just do deserts to go now. Which isn't the end of the world you grab a slice of chocolate cake and when you take it home and eat it you are reminded why you keep on going there even if the feeling is short lived.3 weeks later when you go back they say they are renovating and you will be able to get a slice of cake soon but wont tell you when and all the cooks went to work at different resturaunts.You go to visit these resturaunts every so often and you can taste their contribution to the meal and it tastes good but it isn't the otherworldly decidence provided by the original meals you enjoyed.Then it happens, after years of renovation signs and promises from the owners and chefs, they finally announce they will never open their doors again...You know that if they ever did open up again it might fall short of your expectations, but that haunting memory of that excuisite cake keeps you up at night. You continue living going from bakery to sweet shop trying to find it's equal or even something to put your mind at ease to know that that level of quality can be matched. Instead the truth is that every single sweet treat you put on your tongue brings your closer and closer to the realization that nothing will ever measure up and you are doomed to an eternity of trying to find anything to measure up but you know you never will.THIS IS WHAT YOU HAVE DONE TO ME VALVE!!!! I HATE HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU!!!!!!

Posted: April 25, 2014
												There's not much that can be said about this game that hasn't been already shouted out a thousand times. All in all the game and it's engine have aged beautifully. I still think the game looks perfect in comparison with the most recent releases. And the story; it's a seller - it grasps you like no other. But the best part about this game is the solid, easy, fun and addicting gameplay.And what about the replay value, you might ask? Well the game is filled with easter eggs and secrets for you to find if you're into digging around a bit. I sure am since I've collected all the Steam achievements this game had to offer. Lot's of fun!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												Half-Life 2 lives up to its name by providing an endearing story with likable characters and an overlooming threat that our favourite silent hero from the first HL game, Gordon Freeman, must rise up and defeat. It remains entertaining even all the way through to Episode 1 and 2, contains unique weapons, great graphics that stand out even today, and an excellent game engine that is still being used by Valve and indie game devs in this day and age. While there are some weapons that just don't feel right in this game whether it's how they feel when firing them or simply holding them and the game has a bad habit of repeating itself in certain instances, I felt HL2 is an excellent game that got's flaws, but that can forgiven for what it delivers in its 15-hour journey.

content:

												Experience on Linux so far:- Mouse sensitivity issues, may have been resolved now.The game:You know what it is! Half-life was and still is epic, although I think it's time for Gordon to rest and let Valve focus on entirely new games. Not everyone agrees and I know a large crowd of people are feverishly waiting for HL3. Hopefully, it will have a Linux port on the same release date as the other versions and I will happily preorder to make that happen.By current standards, this is an old game and comparing it to newer titles it does show. Still a "need to own" title.I still think HL1 was better and more groundbreaking back in it's day, but hey, HL is HL.The score:3/5

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												I finally began to play Half-life 2 after it sat in my steam library for around 2 years. I finally decided to start playing because I was intrigued. I wanted to see what made this game so highly acclaimed. So much of my game time was spent trying to find the answer to a single question: "Why is Half-life 2 so great?" For a majority of the game I struggled to find the answer. It wasn't that I didn't like the game, it was just I couldn't understand why it was considered to be so amazing. I considered the possibility that the game may have had a different charm back in 2004 when it was released, but the more I played, the more I realized there was much more to the greatness of this game. Onward I struggled with this question and continued to ask myself about what elements made this game so heralded.Was it because of the beloved source engine?Was it because of the quirky and stereotypical FPS story?Was it because of the amazing powers of the gravity gun?Was it because of how well the graphics held up to this day?Was it because of the unique characters?Was it because of the excellent shooting mechanics?Or was it because of the absence of any cutscenes in the game?No, all of these things were good, but they weren't the elements that made Half-life 2 great.The more I searched, the more I realized I was overlooking the one single determining factor in the ability of a game to please its audience. Enjoyment. So I asked myself the question: "Is Half-life 2 fun?" In asking this I realized that what Half-life 2 does so well is the fundamental goal of all games.This is to provide its audience with enjoyment. Half-life 2 does this as well as any game I've ever played. Throughout the game there was never a dull moment. And while all of the elements of this game I mentioned before are great, the game truly excells at making sure you have a good time.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												 It was all in that moment when I just sat back and laughed. I couldn't believe it was quite this good. I chuckled in muddled disbelief, expectations utterly defied. My nervous fingers reloaded the level, knowing that I had to see that breathtaking sequence one more time. It was then that I knew for certain: Valve had surpassed not only themselves, but everyone else too. Half-Life 2 is an astounding accomplishment. It is the definitive statement of the last five years of first-person shooters. Everything else was just a stopgap.Half-Life 2 is a near perfect sequel. It takes almost everything that worked from Half-Life and either improves on it, or keeps it much the same. But that simple summation undersells how the Valve team have approached this task. Half-Life 2 is a linear shooter with most of the refinements one would expect from years of work, but it is also a game of a higher order of magnitude than any of the previous pretenders to the throne. The polish and the stratospheric height of the production values mean that Half-Life 2 is a magnificent, dramatic experience that has few peers.It would be madness for me to spoil this game by talking about the specific turn of events, so spoilers are going to be kept to a minimum. We're going to talk about general processes and the elements of style and design that make Half-Life 2 such an energising experience. Key to this is the way in which Gordon's tale is told. Once again we never leave his perspective. There are no cutscenes, no moment in which you are anything but utterly embedded in Gordon's view of the world. Everything is told through his eyes. And what a story it is. Gordon arrives at the central station at City 17—a disruptive and chilling dystopia. And from there? Well, that would be telling. This is not the contemporary America that Gordon seemed to be living in during the original Half-Life. The events of Black Mesa have affected the whole world. The crossover with Xen has meant that things have altered radically, with hyper-technology existing alongside eastern bloc dereliction.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Ten years and this game is still one of the best Adventure First Person Shooters I've played.But why is this game such a good one, you ask? Well, if you've already played the first Half-LIfe, this is basically the same except a hundred times better in every field. More immersive story, new weapons, new minor and major characters, and HUUUGE graphic improvements with bugs and glitches few and far between. My only problem is that the lighting tends to glitch out at random intervals and requires you to restart the game to maybe fix it.If you haven't? Well, I guess you'll have to trust me that you're in for one hell of a story for this one. Even (mostly) during the cinematic parts, you still have minor control over the game. Practically everything else is left for you to do.The story starts with Gordon Freeman, a Theoretical Physicist and former Black Mesa employee, newly arriving in a mysterious place called City Seventeen. Eventually after wandering around in the train station you meet an old friend Barney Calhoun, also a former Black Mesa Employee. Before you know it, you're running around in an apartment building being chased by the police.The rest of the story is for you to experience.Trust me, this game is worth your ten bucks.

 Half-Life 2 - Pro's & Con's Before I begin my review, I'd wish to pronounce a disclaimer: A majority of what I'll claim within this review consists of facts based upon that of amoderate computer system Now that everything has been exclaimed, we shall begin the review. Con's: Story contains several unnecessary plot pointsLacks missing content"Full Game" requires the purchase of 2 other 'Episodes'Lacks a large diversity when it comes to enemy choicesGraphics arn't quality for it's time of release (2004)----------------------------------------------------------------------- Pro's: The Revolutionary Source Engine was improved durastically for this titleMany modifications to try out (Aside from the base game)Game lasts a good 7-11 hoursPhysics were very intricate for it's time (2004)For the story it did have, it executed itself wellSound design was exceptionally decentOverall atmosphere compliments gameplayGood character developmentSilent protaganist adds to story's tensionsGame led to various iconic moments and things in gaming history-----------------------------------------------------------------------Overall, I feel that although the game isn't perfect, I'd still HIGHLY reccomend getting this game!

Posted: December 23, 2015
												Who wouldn't know Half-Life 2? At least here on Steam, Valve's online distribution platform? The game that brought fame and the main reason for people actually installing Steam (at first at least)?No introductions are necessary, Half-Life 2 is the perfect first-person shooter that introduced a revolutionary engine, that still looks very good even by today's standards (just take a look at the water or the shiny tip of the crowbar) with excellent physics (introduced in Jurassic Park Tresspasser) and had memorable action scenes (not really something first-person shooters were known for at that time, except the original Unreal, Deus-Ex and maybe Far Cry).And of course who wouldn't remember the fast paced chase sequence with the airboat trying to the shake off the helicopter behind us? Or the first time we grabbed the gravity gun either in it's "normal" or overcharged state? The spooky zombie infested old town section? The prison assault commandeering the giant insects, the antlions?Valve successfully managed to create from Half-Life's silent protagonist a (still silent) superhero for Half-Life 2, who can turn the tide and fight off the puppets of an unknown invading alien species: Gordon Freeman. The secret is that it's completely from his (or rather your) perspective with no interruption of cutscenes and no third-person camera view. Also after loading screens there are no breaks between the sections so you really get the illusion of having travelled a long way.What I loved the most is the atmosphere and the semi-post-apocalyptic urban setting. The ravaged blocks of flats or the ruined houses along the (still) beautiful coastline and the police state controlled society reminiscent of Orwell's 1984, are the greatest strength of the game in my opinion. It's really immersive.Half-Life 2 has its flaws however. We get no explanation whatsoever regarding most things (why is the mysterious man with the suitcase called G man and who is he anyway - a constant riddle left over from the original Half-Life) leaving us only guessing and the further episodes (which are also very good) can't really shed more light on the plot, leading us to believe that the creators didn't really focus on the storyline and were thinking 'aah, we're going to figure out something later on'. Too bad, because with a decent story Half-Life 2 could have been the GAME.Still it is one of the best games in gaming history and everyone who has a registered steam account should give it a try. It is a very memorable experience (along with its sequels, Episode 1 & 2) and maybe Valve should make its playthrough obligatory for new users in their subscriber agreement (for free of course :))PROS+ amazing graphics, water effects, even on weaker systems+ excellent engine with great physics+ good sound effects and voice acting+ high-speed chase sequences+ beautiful, diverse scenery and great overall atmosphereCONS- story is functional- due to scripting some enemies are impossible to kill early onRATING9/10

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												The game is so ridiculously good in every aspect that it’s hard to stay objective while writing about it. If you like shooters at all I highly recommend trying Half-Life 2. Even for it’s age it looks good and there is a ton of reasons why to pick it:1.	The story is captivating and original2.	Designwise a very clean representation of a dystopian/ post-soviet community 3.	Fluent natural controls. There’s a lot of precision-jumping, climbing and moving on narrow edges in the game and the controls are there to help you. Half-Life 2 has found just the right balance to make you forget about controls in the whole.4.	To date I haven’t encountered a bug that would have broke the gameplay5.	The game is humorous where appropriate6.	Some of the most memorable characters of my entire gaming history7.	Levels are very different, never repetitive.8.	Cool weapons/ large variety of enemies9.	Atmospheric music/ sound effects10.	Immense replay value11.	Challenging puzzles. Puzzles play an important role in Half-Life 212.	A good dose of horror. Though there are some scary sequences your character is just the kind of tough ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to deal with them.My only problem is that in between gameplay, the story sequences are not the shortest and there’s no way to skip them which can become tedious on the 5th playthrough. But through years I’ve always come back to it, that’s how good it is.

												Half-Life 2 is a First-Person shooter developed by Valve, and is considered one of the greatest games of all time... with good reason. Half-Life 2 has some of the coolest elements I have ever seen in a game.Pros:-Great Narrative is continued through a total FP perspective like Half-Life-Well designed characters -Fun weapons, even cooler than Half-Life-REALLY GOOD GRAPHICS (When I first played this game I thought it was a recently made game, but NOPE this game was made in 2004... 2004!!!)-Variety of scenarios (You will be doing different things throughout the game and not just killing anything that moves)Cons:-At times some of the levels can be long and barren especially in the Highway 17 section-Physics engine can be a pain sometimes especially in the Water Hazard  chapter where your air boat can be flipped over and you can't easily put it back up-No Half-Life 3Overall, (9.7/10) Half-Life 2 is a MUST HAVE for any steam user, despite minimal flaws this game is almost perfect. Now go get The Orange Box or GabeN will find you.

 Half-Life 2 - Pro's & Con's Before I begin my review, I'd wish to pronounce a disclaimer: A majority of what I'll claim within this review consists of facts based upon that of amoderate computer system Now that everything has been exclaimed, we shall begin the review. Con's: Story contains several unnecessary plot pointsLacks missing content"Full Game" requires the purchase of 2 other 'Episodes'Lacks a large diversity when it comes to enemy choicesGraphics arn't quality for it's time of release (2004)----------------------------------------------------------------------- Pro's: The Revolutionary Source Engine was improved durastically for this titleMany modifications to try out (Aside from the base game)Game lasts a good 7-11 hoursPhysics were very intricate for it's time (2004)For the story it did have, it executed itself wellSound design was exceptionally decentOverall atmosphere compliments gameplayGood character developmentSilent protaganist adds to story's tensionsGame led to various iconic moments and things in gaming history-----------------------------------------------------------------------Overall, I feel that although the game isn't perfect, I'd still HIGHLY reccomend getting this game!

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Half-Life is one of Valve's main franchises, the first game was a huge success, and its long awaited sequel, Half-Life 2, did not disappoint. At its core it's just like your everyday FPS, you go through places, kill some dudes, same old action. However, it's a special game. But why, you ask?When you talk about this game to people who've never played it, they often wonder why does everyone hail it as an amazing masterpiece. Here's the thing. You can't grasp the reason why Half-Life 2 is what it is. I mean, you could try, but it's really one of those games you simply need to experience.Everyone who wants to know how a good FPS is made should play this game. First, its story. It has a surprisingly deep plot that doesn't quite fully show itself to you straight away, and requires attention to detail to understand, though playing the first game will obviously help in this regard.The plot doesn't get too convoluted to the point of not making sense, or too simple to not make you care. That's not to say there won't be moments where you will be wondering what is even going on, but they don't happen out of thin air, and have an explanation, or will have in the future I'm certain, once Valve gets around to continuing the franchise.Yes, it's true, Gordon Freeman doesn't talk, but when you think about it, he doesn't need to. The game does an outstanding job in showing you everything that's happening without Freeman needing to utter a word. He doesn't need to have a preset personality that may conflict with yours and ultimately diminish your enjoyment of the game. What you do, he does. Who you are, he is.Just like the first game, it heavily uses its visuals to tell the story, rather than a static wall of text. This only helps keep it its excellent fluid pacing, feeding you pieces of information as you go along, but not keeping you too much in one place before the action resumes. Having been the first game released with the Source engine, along with Troika's amazing RPG Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines, this game looked great, and still does to this day.But just like I already mentioned in this review, only by playing through Half-Life 2 can you see why it's gathered the amazing fanbase it has, and why it's such a great singleplayer experience. What are you waiting for!? It's super cheap. Go get it and play it now! And Episode 1 and 2 right after, because I bet after completing HL2 you'll want to go through those as well. And then you may join the legion of gamers anxiously waiting for Episode 3.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												This game is no doubt a masterpiece. When I initially played this game a long time ago, I didn't like it. I thought it was just a generic sci fi FPS with a mediocre story. After giving this game another go years later, I finally understand this game. There is far more to Half-Life 2 if you're willing to dig a little deeper. The entire game manages to create this very surreal and mysterious atmosphere that really creates a very unique tone. The level design is fantastic. It manages to guide you through nonlinear areas without giving you a map or checkpoints. The characters are all very distinct and interesting. Each character contributes to the game in very idiosyncratic ways. Every aspect of this game seems to come together to create a very peculiar effect that matches nothing I've ever seen before. Half-Life 2 is a very fine example as to how video games are an art and have the ability to evoke meaningful and thought provoking feelings.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I don't think anyone really needs to read my drip of a review in the already thriving ocean of love that Half-Life is swimming in, but I'm bored, and you're here.Half-Life 2 improves upon Valve's amazing storytelling sans-cutscenes and through environmental cues and wonderful voice acting in its NPCs. You are still Gordon Freeman and still as silent as ever, soaking it all in. Some say that he is an empty husk devoid of character, while others treat his silence as an opportunity to let themselves react to the events in the world around them rather than being told how Gordon feels; YOU are Gordon Freeman.The Source engine was debuted in HL2 and there are many little physics 'puzzles', to use the word generously, that show off the engine's bells and whistles. The gravity gun is really where it shines though.The AI is competent (any veteran FPS player will have to play on the hardest difficulty setting), and there are many wonderful action set-pieces in well-fleshed out locales.That's about all I can say here; I may share my thoughts on Episodes 1 and 2 at a later date.Until then, happy headcrab hunting.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2013
												I consider Half-Life 2 to be one of the best single player first person shooters ever created.  At the time of release it was groundbreaking and almost a decade later there are still few FPS out there that can stand up to it.  The level design, the immersive atmosphere, the innovative use of physics, the graphics (which still hold up), the structure, the pacing, the characters, the story, the weapons...all are exceptional.  It's a game that can be played over and over.  One negative would be the AI which was decent at the time but feels a little dated now.  That's a minor gripe.  An almost perfect game.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												I highly recommend this game if you don't already have it.  Seriously.  This game is different from other games.  It just felt right when I played this.  Ok so I have over 100 games in my Steam library and I play like a third to a forth of all of them.  I've played the campaigns of Tomb Raider, Saints Row, Far Cry 3, GTA V, Call of Duty, Battlefield, Skyrim, Fallout, Mirrors Edge and Borderlands and yet, I haven't beaten a single one yet, some of them i've had for years.  This game tho and any other Valve game is different.  I've beaten, Portal, Portal 2, Half Life 2 and The Stanley Parable.  You know what they all have in common? They all run on the Source Engine.  Seriously it's one of the best game engines out there, my freaking laptop can play any Source game at 60FPS and my laptop is TERRIBLE. So back to Half life.  This game just felt right, it got me hooked so to say, at least this time around.  I've tried to play it years before and I always got lost or bored, this time around I couldn't stop, I really couldn't.  I would go through school the next day just wanting to come home and play this game. It's just seriously a masterpeice and thats all I can really say.  Just please, if oyu haven't already, don't hesitate to buy this.TL;DR: no, read it.

												Half-Life 2 is put simply one of the best First-Person shooters ever! The story is epic and has you cross the acid canals of City 17, the brutal shores of the coast and the horrible...Nova Prospect. The friendly characters are great and helpful even if they can get in your way. And the evil characters like Dr.Breen I hate with a passion! If you complete the game then It can get dull. To fix this try and get all the achievements! I played HL2 from the start trying to get all the achievements and It made the game so much more fun! A lot of people are like me, they see the achievements and think "I'm NOT getting those" but it is fun! Anyway, just play it. You'll love it!

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												A great prequel to the new hit shooter, Garry's Mod. Though it may not have as big of an audience, it is still a huge contender to the recently successful "Call of Duty: Modern Warfare" series. The story follows two loveable main characters: Dr. Kleiner and his dog, Dog. They struggle to survive in a post-apocalyptic New York amongst the horrifying mutated life caused by the nuclear apocalypse. With a page-turning storyline and its library of amazingly-developed characters, this game amazed even the most experienced of gamers. 4/10 - One of the best games of the decade

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												The combine harvester, or simply combine, is a machine that harvests grain crops. The name derives from its combining three separate operations comprising harvesting—reaping, threshing, and winnowing—into a single process. Among the crops harvested with a combine are wheat, oats, rye, barley, corn (maize), soybeans and flax (linseed). The waste straw left behind on the field is the remaining dried stems and leaves of the crop with limited nutrients which is either chopped and spread on the field or baled for feed and bedding for livestock.Combine harvesters are one of the most economically important labor saving inventions, enabling a small fraction of the population to be engaged in agriculture.HistoryScottish inventor Patrick Bell invented the Reaper in 1826. The combine was invented in the United States by Hiram Moore in 1834, and early versions were pulled by horse or mule teams. In 1835, Moore built a full-scale version and by 1839, over 50 acres of crops were harvested. By 1860, combine harvesters with a cutting width of several metres were used on American farms. In 1882, the Australian Hugh Victor McKay had a similar idea and developed the first commercial combine harvester in 1885, the Sunshine Harvester.Combines, some of them quite large, were drawn by mule or horse teams and used a bullwheel to provide power. Later, steam power was used, and George Stockton Berry integrated the combine with a steam engine using straw to heat the boiler. Tractor-drawn, combines became common after World War II as many farms began to use tractors. These combines used a shaker to separate the grain from the chaff and straw-walkers (grates with small teeth on an eccentric shaft) to eject the straw while retaining the grain. Early tractor-drawn combines were usually powered by a separate gasoline engine, while later models were PTO-powered. These machines either put the harvested crop into bags that were then loaded onto a wagon or truck, or had a small bin that stored the grain until it was transferred to a truck or wagon with an auger.In the U.S., Allis-Chalmers, Massey-Harris, International Harvester, Gleaner Manufacturing Company, John Deere, and Minneapolis Moline are past or present major combine producers.In 1911, the Holt Manufacturing Company of California produced a self-propelled harvester. In Australia in 1923, the patented Sunshine Auto Header was one of the first center-feeding self-propelled harvesters.[8] In 1923 in Kansas, the Curtis brothers and their Gleaner Manufacturing Company patented a self-propelled harvester which included several other modern improvements in grain handling.[9] Both the Gleaner and the Sunshine used Fordson engines. In 1929 Alfredo Rotania of Argentina patented a self-propelled harvester.[10] In 1937, the Australian-born Thomas Carroll, working for Massey-Harris in Canada, perfected a self-propelled model and in 1940 a lighter-weight model began to be marketed widely by the company.[11] Lyle Yost invented an auger that would lift grain out of a combine in 1947, making unloading grain much easier.[12]In 1952 Claeys launched the first self- propelled combine harvester in Europe;[13] in 1953, the European manufacturer CLAAS developed a self-propelled combine harvester named 'Herkules', it could harvest up to 5 tons of wheat a day.[14] This newer kind of combine is still in use and is powered by diesel or gasoline engines. Until the self-cleaning rotary screen was invented in the mid-1960s combine engines suffered from overheating as the chaff spewed out when harvesting small grains would clog radiators, blocking the airflow needed for cooling.A significant advance in the design of combines was the rotary design. The grain is initially stripped from the stalk by passing along a helical rotor instead of passing between rasp bars on the outside of a cylinder and a concave. Rotary combines were first introduced by Sperry-New Holland in 1975.[15]In about the 1980s on-board electronics were introduced to measure threshing efficiency. This new instrumentation allowed operators to get better grain yields by optimizing ground speed and other operating parameters.A John Deere 9410 Combine with grain platform attached.A John Deere Titan series combine unloading corn.Combine heads[edit]Combines are equipped with removable heads that are designed for particular crops. The standard header, sometimes called a grain platform, is equipped with a reciprocating knife cutter bar, and features a revolving reel with metal or plastic teeth to cause the cut crop to fall into the auger once it is cut. A variation of the platform, a "flex" platform, is similar but has a cutter bar that can flex over contours and ridges to cut soybeans that have pods close to the ground. A flex head can cut soybeans as well as cereal crops, while a rigid platform is generally used only in cereal grains.Some wheat headers, called "draper" headers, hi use a fabric or rubber apron instead of a cross auger. Draper headers allow faster feeding than cross augers, leading to higher throughputs due to lower power requirements. On many farms, platform headers are used to cut wheat, instead of separate wheat headers, so as to reduce overall costs.Dummy heads or pick-up headers feature spring-tined pickups, usually attached to a heavy rubber belt. They are used for crops that have already been cut and placed in windrows or swaths. This is particularly useful in northern climates such as western Canada where swathing kills weeds resulting in a faster dry down.While a grain platform can be used for corn, a specialized corn head is ordinarily used instead. The corn head is equipped with snap rolls that strip the stalk and leaf away from the ear, so that only the ear (and husk) enter the throat. This improves efficiency dramatically since so much less material must go through the cylinder. The corn head can be recognized by the presence of points between each row.Occasionally rowcrop heads are seen that function like a grain platform, but have points between rows like a corn head. These are used to reduce the amount of weed seed picked up when harvesting small grains.Self-propelled Gleaner combines could be fitted with special tracks instead of tires or tires with tread measuring almost 10in deep to assist in harvesting rice. Some combines, particularly pull type, have tires with a diamond tread which prevents sinking in mud. These tracks can fit other combines by having adapter plates made.The cut crop is carried up the feeder throat (commonly called the "feederhouse") by a chain and flight elevator, then fed into the threshing mechanism of the combine, consisting of a rotating threshing drum (commonly called the "cylinder"), to which grooved steel bars (rasp bars) are bolted. The rasp bars thresh or separate the grains and chaff from the straw through the action of the cylinder against the concave, a shaped "half drum", also fitted with steel bars and a meshed grill, through which grain, chaff and smaller debris may fall, whereas the straw, being too long, is carried through onto the straw walkers. This action is also allowed due to the fact that the grain is heavier than the straw, which causes it to fall rather than "float" across from the cylinder/concave to the walkers. The drum speed is variably adjustable on most machines, whilst the distance between the drum and concave is finely adjustable fore, aft and together, to achieve optimum separation and output. Manually engaged disawning plates are usually fitted to the concave. These provide extra friction to remove the awns from barley crops.

												Rise and shine, Mister Freeman. Rise and shine. Not that I wish to imply you have been sleeping on the job. No one is more deserving of a rest, and all the gaming in the world would have gone to waste until... well, let's just say we need you again.The right game in the wrong place can make all the difference in the world. So, wake up, Mister Freeman. Wake up and... smell the ashes...Seriously though, we need a sequel. I don't care if it runs on the same engine, or if it doesn't have some revolutonary feature. I just really want to conclude Gordon's story and feel the old rush of playing a new Half-Life game.

Posted: April 9, 2014
												The combine harvester, or simply combine, is a machine that harvests grain crops. The name derives from its combining three separate operations comprising harvesting—reaping, threshing, and winnowing—into a single process. Among the crops harvested with a combine are wheat, oats, rye, barley, corn (maize), soybeans and flax (linseed). The waste straw left behind on the field is the remaining dried stems and leaves of the crop with limited nutrients which is either chopped and spread on the field or baled for feed and bedding for livestock.Combine harvesters are one of the most economically important labor saving inventions, enabling a small fraction of the population to be engaged in agriculture.HistoryScottish inventor Patrick Bell invented the Reaper in 1826. The combine was invented in the United States by Hiram Moore in 1834, and early versions were pulled by horse or mule teams. In 1835, Moore built a full-scale version and by 1839, over 50 acres of crops were harvested. By 1860, combine harvesters with a cutting width of several metres were used on American farms. In 1882, the Australian Hugh Victor McKay had a similar idea and developed the first commercial combine harvester in 1885, the Sunshine Harvester.Combines, some of them quite large, were drawn by mule or horse teams and used a bullwheel to provide power. Later, steam power was used, and George Stockton Berry integrated the combine with a steam engine using straw to heat the boiler. Tractor-drawn, combines became common after World War II as many farms began to use tractors. These combines used a shaker to separate the grain from the chaff and straw-walkers (grates with small teeth on an eccentric shaft) to eject the straw while retaining the grain. Early tractor-drawn combines were usually powered by a separate gasoline engine, while later models were PTO-powered. These machines either put the harvested crop into bags that were then loaded onto a wagon or truck, or had a small bin that stored the grain until it was transferred to a truck or wagon with an auger.In the U.S., Allis-Chalmers, Massey-Harris, International Harvester, Gleaner Manufacturing Company, John Deere, and Minneapolis Moline are past or present major combine producers.In 1911, the Holt Manufacturing Company of California produced a self-propelled harvester. In Australia in 1923, the patented Sunshine Auto Header was one of the first center-feeding self-propelled harvesters.[8] In 1923 in Kansas, the Curtis brothers and their Gleaner Manufacturing Company patented a self-propelled harvester which included several other modern improvements in grain handling.[9] Both the Gleaner and the Sunshine used Fordson engines. In 1929 Alfredo Rotania of Argentina patented a self-propelled harvester.[10] In 1937, the Australian-born Thomas Carroll, working for Massey-Harris in Canada, perfected a self-propelled model and in 1940 a lighter-weight model began to be marketed widely by the company.[11] Lyle Yost invented an auger that would lift grain out of a combine in 1947, making unloading grain much easier.[12]In 1952 Claeys launched the first self- propelled combine harvester in Europe;[13] in 1953, the European manufacturer CLAAS developed a self-propelled combine harvester named 'Herkules', it could harvest up to 5 tons of wheat a day.[14] This newer kind of combine is still in use and is powered by diesel or gasoline engines. Until the self-cleaning rotary screen was invented in the mid-1960s combine engines suffered from overheating as the chaff spewed out when harvesting small grains would clog radiators, blocking the airflow needed for cooling.A significant advance in the design of combines was the rotary design. The grain is initially stripped from the stalk by passing along a helical rotor instead of passing between rasp bars on the outside of a cylinder and a concave. Rotary combines were first introduced by Sperry-New Holland in 1975.[15]In about the 1980s on-board electronics were introduced to measure threshing efficiency. This new instrumentation allowed operators to get better grain yields by optimizing ground speed and other operating parameters.A John Deere 9410 Combine with grain platform attached.A John Deere Titan series combine unloading corn.Combine heads[edit]Combines are equipped with removable heads that are designed for particular crops. The standard header, sometimes called a grain platform, is equipped with a reciprocating knife cutter bar, and features a revolving reel with metal or plastic teeth to cause the cut crop to fall into the auger once it is cut. A variation of the platform, a "flex" platform, is similar but has a cutter bar that can flex over contours and ridges to cut soybeans that have pods close to the ground. A flex head can cut soybeans as well as cereal crops, while a rigid platform is generally used only in cereal grains.Some wheat headers, called "draper" headers, hi use a fabric or rubber apron instead of a cross auger. Draper headers allow faster feeding than cross augers, leading to higher throughputs due to lower power requirements. On many farms, platform headers are used to cut wheat, instead of separate wheat headers, so as to reduce overall costs.Dummy heads or pick-up headers feature spring-tined pickups, usually attached to a heavy rubber belt. They are used for crops that have already been cut and placed in windrows or swaths. This is particularly useful in northern climates such as western Canada where swathing kills weeds resulting in a faster dry down.While a grain platform can be used for corn, a specialized corn head is ordinarily used instead. The corn head is equipped with snap rolls that strip the stalk and leaf away from the ear, so that only the ear (and husk) enter the throat. This improves efficiency dramatically since so much less material must go through the cylinder. The corn head can be recognized by the presence of points between each row.Occasionally rowcrop heads are seen that function like a grain platform, but have points between rows like a corn head. These are used to reduce the amount of weed seed picked up when harvesting small grains.Self-propelled Gleaner combines could be fitted with special tracks instead of tires or tires with tread measuring almost 10in deep to assist in harvesting rice. Some combines, particularly pull type, have tires with a diamond tread which prevents sinking in mud. These tracks can fit other combines by having adapter plates made.The cut crop is carried up the feeder throat (commonly called the "feederhouse") by a chain and flight elevator, then fed into the threshing mechanism of the combine, consisting of a rotating threshing drum (commonly called the "cylinder"), to which grooved steel bars (rasp bars) are bolted. The rasp bars thresh or separate the grains and chaff from the straw through the action of the cylinder against the concave, a shaped "half drum", also fitted with steel bars and a meshed grill, through which grain, chaff and smaller debris may fall, whereas the straw, being too long, is carried through onto the straw walkers. This action is also allowed due to the fact that the grain is heavier than the straw, which causes it to fall rather than "float" across from the cylinder/concave to the walkers. The drum speed is variably adjustable on most machines, whilst the distance between the drum and concave is finely adjustable fore, aft and together, to achieve optimum separation and output. Manually engaged disawning plates are usually fitted to the concave. These provide extra friction to remove the awns from barley crops.
